input: Hello doctor,The color of the skin on my face is too dark when compared to the skin on my nose, cheeks, and rest of my body. How can I restore the original color on my face?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. The skin often darkens due to tanning under the effect of UV (ultraviolet) rays. I would strongly recommend using a sunscreen with a minimum SPF of 30. The sunscreen has to be applied at least half an hour before you go out and has to be reapplied every four hours till evening. I suggest trying skin lightening cream like Biluma (Kojic acid) at night. Alternatively, you could visit your dermatologist for chemical peels like Lactic acid or Glycolic acid peels. Whatever be the treatment, sun protection is a must. Hope this helped. Take care. For more information consult a dermatologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! There are several possible reasons why the skin on your face is darker than the skin on other parts of your body, such as sun damage, hormonal changes, or genetics. Here are some steps you can take to restore the original color on your face:

1. Protect your skin from the sun: Use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30 every day, even when it's cloudy outside. Wear a hat and sunglasses to protect your face from the sun.

2. Treat hyperpigmentation: You can use over-the-counter creams and serums that contain ingredients like hydroquinone, kojic acid, or vitamin C to reduce hyperpigmentation and even out your skin tone. However, it's important to use these products as directed and consult with a dermatologist if you have any concerns.

3. Exfoliate regularly: Exfoliation can help remove dead skin cells and reveal brighter, smoother skin. You can use a gentle scrub, a chemical exfoliant like glycolic acid, or a facial brush.

4. Maintain a healthy diet: Eating a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains can help improve your skin's health and appearance. Foods like tomatoes, citrus fruits, and leafy greens contain antioxidants and vitamins that can help reduce inflammation and promote skin health.

5. Seek professional help: If home remedies don't work, you can consider visiting a dermatologist who can assess your skin concerns and recommend treatments like chemical peels or laser therapy.

Remember, restoring your skin's original color may take time, patience, and consistency, and it's important to take a holistic approach by protecting your skin from the sun, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and seeking professional help if needed.

Hello! I understand that receiving unexpected lab results can be concerning. Here is a brief explanation of each result:

1. RDW-CV: This stands for Red Blood Cell Distribution Width - Coefficient of Variation. It is a measure of the variation in size of red blood cells. A value of 14.4 is slightly elevated, but not typically considered significant on its own.

2. Eosinophils: These are a type of white blood cell that can indicate allergies, parasitic infections, or other conditions. A value of 9.1 is definitely elevated and warrants further evaluation.

3. Absolute eosinophil count: This is a measure of the number of eosinophils present in the blood. A value of 0.70 is high and also suggests further evaluation.

4. Thyroid profile: This includes measures of three hormones that regulate metabolism. The ultra-sensitive TSH test is the most important measure for determining thyroid function. A value of 7.244 indicates higher thyroid stimulating hormone levels than normal, which could indicate an underactive thyroid.

Based on these results, it would be a good idea to follow up with your doctor. They can help you interpret the results and recommend any further testing or treatment that may be necessary.

input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. A regular pill has to be taken regularly for 21 days daily without any gap, and then they are stopped for a week (for periods). Again, they are retaken for 21 days. It can be taken for two to three years together. At that time, you have to avoid pregnancy. I-pill has to be consumed within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. All these are low dose pills with minimum side effects.
answer_chatgpt:
Regular contraceptive pills are taken daily to prevent pregnancy by suppressing ovulation, thickening cervical mucus to block sperm from reaching the egg and thinning the lining of the uterus to make it difficult for a fertilized egg to implant. They are also known as birth control pills and are not intended for use after unprotected sex.

Emergency contraceptive pills, on the other hand, are taken within a few days after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. They work primarily by preventing ovulation, but they may also prevent the fertilization of an egg or the implantation of a fertilized egg. The i-pill is an example of an emergency contraceptive pill.

So, to answer your question, the i-pill is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy and is meant to be used as an emergency contraceptive. Regular contraceptive pills are taken daily to prevent pregnancy and are not intended for emergency use.
answer_chatdoctor: 1. Emergency pills are used when you had unprotected sexual intercourse or if your birth control method fails(in this case it can be used as a regular method). They contain high doses of hormone which prevent ovulation and fertilization.2. Regular pills are used regularly for birth control. They contain lower doses of hormones which prevent ovulation and also thicken cervical mucus thus preventing sperm penetration into uterine cavity.3. The difference is that the emergency pill contains higher dosage of hormones and has to be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse while the regular pill requires to be taken every day at same time.

Hello! The tablets you are taking are used to regulate your menstrual cycle and manage PCOS symptoms. B-long tablet contains B vitamins and folic acid, which support fertility and healthy egg development. APCOD sachets contain inositol, a compound that has been shown to improve insulin resistance and hormonal balance in women with PCOS. Dronis-30 is a contraceptive pill that can help regulate menstrual cycles and control PCOS symptoms. 

PCOS is a condition that affects women's hormones, causing irregular periods, acne, weight gain, and fertility problems. It is caused by hormonal imbalances that affect ovulation and egg development. The tender breasts you are experiencing could be related to hormonal changes during your cycle. 

To improve your chances of conceiving, your doctor may recommend lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, a healthy diet, and weight management. You may also benefit from fertility treatments such as ovulation induction or in vitro fertilization (IVF). 

It's important to continue working closely with your doctor to manage your PCOS and optimize your fertility. Additionally, managing PCOS can have long-term benefits for your overall health and wellbeing.

The B-Long tablets contain a combination of a progesterone and estrogen hormones which will help regulate your cycles and ovulation. They can also be prescribed if you have difficulty getting pregnant due to problems with ovulating regularly. The APCOD tablets contain a levonorgestrel pill which will help induce ovulation. The Dronis-30 contains a synthetic version of the female hormone progesterone, which helps maintain a pregnancy once conception has occurred. It is usually taken for three weeks after conception. Hope this helps.

If you're going horse riding and hiking and are worried about protecting the toenail, you can wear closed-toe shoes that fit well and have enough space to allow for comfortable movement. You can also wear toe protectors or toe caps to provide an extra layer of protection for the toe.

If you notice any signs of infection such as redness, swelling, discharge, or increasing pain, you should seek medical attention immediately. It's important to keep the area clean and dry to prevent infection.

If you have any concerns or questions, I recommend following up with the doctor who treated your injury or seeking medical advice from another healthcare professional.

The reason for the delay in your period could be due to several factors, including stress, changes in diet or exercise routine, and hormonal imbalances. It is also possible that you are pregnant, although this is unlikely given that you had protected sex and your partner ejaculated outside of the condom. I would recommend taking a pregnancy test and consulting with your healthcare provider to rule out any possible underlying issues, such as a hormonal imbalance or infection.

Hello! Sorry to hear that you're experiencing pain and swelling after your wisdom teeth removal. It's not uncommon to have some discomfort and swelling during the recovery period.

Here are some things you can do to alleviate your symptoms:

1. Apply an ice pack: You can use an ice pack on the affected area for 20 minutes at a time. This will help reduce swelling and pain.

2. Take pain medication: Over-the-counter pain medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help alleviate pain and swelling. Follow the recommended dosage on the label.

3. Gargle with saltwater: Mix one teaspoon of salt in a glass of warm water and gargle with it. This can help reduce inflammation and promote healing.

4. Eat soft foods: Stick to soft foods like soup, yogurt, and mashed potatoes in the first few days after the surgery.

If the swelling and pain persist or worsen, I recommend contacting your dentist or oral surgeon for further evaluation. They may want to examine the area to rule out any complications like infection or dry socket.

answer_chatgpt:
As an AI language model, I cannot become a doctor, diagnose or recommend treatments; however, I can provide some information about muscular dystrophy.

Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders that affect the muscles, causing weakness and progressive damage over time. Unfortunately, at the moment, there is no cure for muscular dystrophy. However, several treatments can help manage symptoms and slow the progression of the disease.

The most effective way to control muscular dystrophy is by working with a team of healthcare professionals to develop a personalized treatment plan. Treatment options include:

1. Physical therapy and exercise: Regular physical therapy and exercise can help improve muscle strength and mobility.

2. Medications: Certain medications can help manage symptoms such as pain, inflammation, and muscle weakness.

3. Surgery: Surgery may be an option in some cases to improve mobility or correct orthopedic problems.

4. Assistive devices: The use of assistive devices such as braces, wheelchairs, and scooters can help individuals with muscular dystrophy remain independent and mobile.

5. Gene therapy: Some types of muscular dystrophy may be treated with gene therapy, a new and emerging technique that aims to correct the underlying genetic mutations responsible for the disease.

It's important to work with a healthcare professional who specializes in muscular dystrophy to create a treatment plan that works best for you or your loved one.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, I am Chat Doctor.. In my opinion, there is no specific treatment for muscular dystrophies. But physical therapy and exercise can help improve function and maintain or increase strength. Surgery may be required in some cases if joint contractures develop. In general, people with muscular dystrophy should avoid activities that require excessive exertion of their muscles. This includes sports that involve running and jumping.

input: Hello doctor,Can I get pregnant without having sperm released inside my vagina during the intercourse? How can I confirm if I maybe pregnant? If I am pregnant what should I do for abortion without surgical means?
answer_icliniq: Hi. Until there is ejaculation in the vagina or precum, there is no chance of pregnancy. So relax and do not worry. However, if you have a doubt then take an emergency contraceptive pill within 72 hours of intercourse. There is no chance of pregnancy. However, if you have crossed 72 hours of intercourse then please do not take any medication without expert advice. If you happen to miss your period then get a urine pregnancy test done with an early morning urine sample to ensure that you are not pregnant. However, if you have a doubt then get back to me.  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Dear user,

Pregnancy can occur when sperm are released inside the vagina during intercourse. However, it is possible but rare to get pregnant without sperm being released, for example, if sperm are present on fingers or other objects and are then introduced to the vagina.

To confirm pregnancy, you can take a pregnancy test. These can be purchased at most drugstores and can detect the pregnancy hormone, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), in your urine. You can use a home pregnancy test or have your healthcare provider do a blood test.

However, if you have concerns about a possible pregnancy or any symptoms that may be related to a pregnancy, I advise you to schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider as soon as possible.

Regarding abortion, I highly recommend talking with your healthcare provider and getting proper medical advice. There are both surgical and non-surgical options for abortion, and the type of abortion that is recommended may depend on factors such as how far along the pregnancy is and your medical history. It is important to seek medical care from a qualified healthcare provider, as self-induced abortion can be dangerous and is not recommended.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Yes, pregnancy is possible without ejaculation in the vagina as long as there is some semen present on your partner's penis or hand when he has sex with you.2) The most common way to diagnose pregnancy is by doing a urine test at home. But be sure that you have not been exposed to any radiation (X-rays, CT scan etc.) within the last 6 months because it may cause birth defects. Hope this answers your question.

answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Based on the information you have provided, it seems that the fibroids are causing a significant amount of bleeding during your menstrual cycle. Typically, fibroids do not require treatment unless they cause symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding, pain or discomfort.

Hysterectomy is one of the treatments for fibroids, and it involves removing the uterus. However, it is not always necessary and should only be considered after weighing the benefits and risks carefully.

There are several other treatment options available for fibroids, such as medication to shrink the fibroids or reduce bleeding, intrauterine devices (IUDs) to help control bleeding, or fibroid embolization, which is a non-surgical procedure that blocks the blood supply to the fibroids. Finally, be sure to follow any other recommendations provided by your child's eye doctor, and don't hesitate to ask any questions or voice any concerns that you may have.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 26 year old female. I had got positive pregnancy by the urine test. I scanned by ultrasound but no detection of the fetus. My last period was two months ago. And my missed period was last month. My doctor gave me FOL-XT and Miprogen 200 mg. I am confused about tablets. If I have to take them or not.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Your urine test is weakly positive. It means your pregnancy may have occurred late, hence not detected on ultrasound. Sometimes, in these cases, there is a risk of miscarriage. So, the doctor has given the medicines to protect from such occurrence. You can take it and repeat the pregnancy test every week and ultrasound after two weeks. For more information consult an obstetrician and gynaecologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

The FOL-XT tablet is a combination of folic acid, methylcobalamin, and pyridoxine, which are essential vitamins for the development of the fetus. These vitamins also help prevent birth defects in the baby. The Miprogen 200 mg tablet is a progesterone supplement, which is given to support the early stages of pregnancy.

Since you have not detected the fetus on ultrasound, you might be experiencing a chemical pregnancy, which is a very early miscarriage that occurs before the fetus is visible on an ultrasound.

It is essential to consult with your doctor whether to continue taking these tablets or not, as it depends on your diagnosis and your doctor's recommendation. They might ask you to repeat the ultrasound or perform some blood tests to confirm your pregnancy.

I hope this answer helps you.
answer_chatdoctor: 1. You should wait for your next period to come. If it is delayed for more than a week then get a blood beta Chat Doctor test done. If it is negative then get an early scan done. 2. The medicines that you are taking are just to maintain the hormonal levels till your periods start. You can safely discontinue them once your periods begin. Hope this answers your question. Please feel free to write back if any further clarifications are needed.

input: Hello doctor,I am a male, and from the past two days, I have pain and itching around the anus. The doctor checked and told that it is a thrombosed hemorrhoid. Can you please let me know the treatment for this? Can it be solved by using conservative methods or do I need any surgery? Thanks in advance. Regards.
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. It would be best if you can upload the pictures of the problem before I can comment and recommend anything definitive and specific to you. If I assume that your doctor rightly diagnosed the problem as a thrombosed hemorrhoid, then I suggest you try doing the following: Hope that information helps you to decide the best option for yourself. Revert with more information to a general surgeon online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello, 

Thrombosed hemorrhoids can be quite painful, but the good news is that they often resolve on their own with conservative treatment. 

Here are some things that you can do to help alleviate the symptoms: 

1. Apply a warm compress: Placing a warm, damp cloth over the affected area can help improve blood flow and reduce pain.

2. Take over-the-counter pain relievers: This can help reduce pain and discomfort.

3. Increase your fiber intake: Eating more fiber can help soften your stool and reduce the strain on your hemorrhoids.

4. Drink plenty of water: This can help keep your stool soft and promote regular bowel movements.

5. Topical medications: There are a variety of over-the-counter creams and ointments that can help reduce swelling and relieve pain.

If your symptoms persist, your doctor may recommend surgery to remove the hemorrhoid. However, surgery is usually only necessary if conservative measures are not effective. 

I hope you feel better soon!

Sitz baths can also provide some relief from symptoms.3. Increase fiber intake to prevent constipation.4. Avoid sitting on hard surfaces as much as possible.5. Avoid straining during bowel movements.6. You may need to take laxatives if constipated.7. Apply ice packs to reduce inflammation.8. Avoid spicy foods which can irritate the area.9. You may use zinc oxide suppositories to help heal internal hemorrhoids.10. Topical steroid creams can help with itching.11. Surgery is done only when conservative measures fail to give results. input: Hello doctor,I have been on my birth control Yaz for 10 to 11 months. Last month, I went on a holiday which collapsed with my placebo pill days with period days. So I started the second pack skipping the placebo pills from the previous pack to skip the period. However, ever since I started the second pack, I have been having spotting and later with breakthrough bleeding.So I decided to stop my second pack at the 11th pill to have my period (so together with the previous pill pack, I took 34 active pills before I stopped taking for a period). I took a four-day break as instructed from the pill pack instruction and started a new pack afterward as usual. It has been seven days from now in this new pack, and I had sex with my partner without extra contraception (condom), is it safe?
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. As you were on pill regularly so that ovulation did not occur possibly. This means you are safe most probably, but 100 % accuracy is not there. But for practical purposes, it is almost safe. Take a urine pregnancy test after two to three weeks, and that will confirm it.
answer_chatgpt: It is unlikely that skipping the placebo pills and starting the new pack caused breakthrough bleeding. Breakthrough bleeding is a common side effect of birth control pills, especially in the first few months of use. However, it is always a good idea to use extra contraception (such as a condom) when you have sex during the first 7 days of starting a new pack, as the pill may not have fully taken effect yet. After 7 days of taking the pill correctly, it should provide reliable contraceptive protection.
answer_chatdoctor: 97% of women will not get pregnant if they use oral contraceptives correctly. But there is always that small chance of failure. You have taken the second pack with the period days, so there was no need to take a break between the two packs. Since you did not take the last pill of the second pack, you may have missed out some hormonal protection. This could be one reason for your bleeding. Also, you should have used condoms for additional protection.

input: Hello doctor,I have acne for around five years. Now I am using Cutein tablets. I suddenly got a burning sensation in my stomach. So, now I am using Pantoprazole tablets along with Cutein. Is that effective or injurious?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Cutein tablet contains Iron as one of the ingredients, along with some other vitamins. The iron tablets can give increased acid in the stomach and indigestion. But, if you take both Cutein and Pantoprazole tablets together, the iron will not get absorbed. Therefore, first take Cutein tablet on empty stomach in the morning, and then 30 minutes later take Pantoprazole.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Cutein is a medicine used for the treatment of acne. The medication contains isotretinoin, which is known to cause gastrointestinal side effects such as stomach pain, nausea, and acid reflux. The burning sensation in your stomach might be one of the side effects of Cutein. Therefore, the doctor may have prescribed Pantoprazole to reduce the acid in your stomach and relieve your symptoms.

Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that reduces the amount of acid produced in the stomach. It is effective in reducing the symptoms of acid reflux, gastritis, and other stomach problems. So, using Pantoprazole along with Cutein can be helpful in reducing the gastrointestinal side effects of Cutein. 

However, you should also keep in mind that long-term use of Pantoprazole may cause some side effects such as headache, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Therefore, it is advisable to consult the doctor before using it for an extended period.

Hope this helps!
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Cutein is an antibiotic and should not be used alone as it does not contain any anti-inflammatory properties.2) Pantoprazole is a proton pump inhibitor which will help reduce the burning sensations but may have side effects like acid reflux, nausea etc.3) You can use topical retinoids such as Retinoid cream or tretinoin gel to treat your acne without needing to take any medicines internally.

input: Hi doctor,My fiance and I were fooling around yesterday and I had semen smeared all over my vagina. He was not wearing a condom. We did not have penetrative sex. However, after the encounter, I got nervous and got emergency pills. All this happened about 14 days after my last period. I assumed I was highly fertile and was at risk for pregnancy. P2, I took one about three hours after my vagina was smeared with semen. I took the next pill 12 hours after the first. Here are my questions:1. I really do not want a pregnancy right now. Is it wise if I take a second dose of the pill to completely reduce chances of implantation? Is it safe to take a higher dose of pills to completely eradicate any possibility of pregnancy?2. What else can I do to make sure I am completely out of the woods?3. Also, after seven days, is it okay for me to start taking antibiotics to eradicate any infections passed? Can general antibiotics like Amoxil treat the treatable STI?4. When is the most prudent time to take an HIV test?5. How effective is P2 when taken during ovulation? I did a little research and some said that P2 will not help if it is taken during ovulation. 6. How can I (in case I get pregnant) make the uterus inhospitable for the growth of the embryo? 7. When should I take a pregnancy test?8. What is the safest mode of getting rid of a fertilised egg within the first few weeks?9. My period should be in two weeks or 15 days from now. Is it guarantee that if it delays I am pregnant? Is it also possible for me to have my period yet still be pregnant?10. Lastly, what are the chances in terms of percentage that I might be pregnant without necessarily having penetrative intercourse?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. How are you doing? That is a lot of questions, but all leading to the same answer. An emergency pill is high dose Progesterone, best taken within three days of sex. Best results if taken within 24 hours of sex. Being a high dose Progesterone, the uterine lining becomes very unfavorable for a possible embryo implantation. The lining suddenly becomes very thick. As it is a single dose, the lining cannot stand on its own and it falls off. But you rightly said success depends on which phase of the cycle you took it. If ovulation had just occurred that day, still there are equal chances of pregnancy and miscarriage. About the questions: 1. You should have the second dose. It will improve chance of embryo not getting implanted. 2. Only after you reach the other end you can confirm that you are out of the woods. You will have to wait for the period. 3. You can have antibiotics anyday, Azithromycin, Doxycycline would be a better choice. 4. HIV can be tested any time now and after six months repeated. 5 and 6 already answered. 7. The pregnancy test can be done earliest one day after the expected period. 8. If positive, you will need a scan to confirm intrauterine pregnancy after two weeks, then MTP (medical termination of pregnancy) can be used. 9. Emergency pill disturbs the hormones, so only the pregnancy test will give you some information. 10. Sperms can swim up even from your thighs into the vagina, so the chance of pregnancy is still there.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello, I am an AI language model and not a doctor. However, I can provide you with some general information on your situation based on the available scientific evidence.

1. It is not recommended to take a higher dose or an additional dose of emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) as it can lead to an increased risk of side effects. ECPs are already a high dose of hormones. Taking it more than the recommended dose would not further reduce the chance of pregnancy.

2. Emergency contraceptive pills have shown to be highly effective in preventing pregnancy when taken correctly, but it does not provide protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). If you are concerned about STIs, you should consult your healthcare provider.

3. If you are diagnosed with an STI, your healthcare provider can prescribe an appropriate antibiotic. However, taking antibiotics without a proper diagnosis and prescription can lead to more harm than good.

4. The most recommended time to take an HIV test is after 3 months of exposure. However, you can consult with your healthcare provider for advice specific to your situation.

5. Emergency contraceptive pills can decrease the chance of pregnancy when taken after unprotected sex, even during ovulation. However, the efficacy of ECPs decreases as the days pass after ovulation.

6. It is not recommended to intentionally try to make the uterus inhospitable for the growth of an embryo, as it can be dangerous and potentially life-threatening.

7. The recommended time to take a pregnancy test is after a missed period. However, if you are concerned, you can take a test after 3 weeks of the unprotected encounter.

8. It is not recommended to try to get rid of a fertilized egg. If you suspect you may be pregnant, you should consult with your healthcare provider for options and support.

9. A late period can indicate pregnancy, but it is not a guarantee as periods can be delayed for various reasons. Similarly, it is possible to experience bleeding during pregnancy, but it is not a period.

10. Without penetrative intercourse, the chances of pregnancy are lower, but it is not impossible as pre-ejaculate can contain sperm. The exact percentage of the risk cannot be estimated without knowing more information about the situation.

It is recommended that you consult with your healthcare provider for personalized advice and support regarding your situation.
answer_chatdoctor: 1. The emergency contraceptive pill is only 75-89% effective in preventing a pregnancy. It is best used as soon as possible after unprotected sex, but you may take it up to 72 hours after unprotected sex. You would need to use another form of birth control for the rest of your cycle until you have regular menstrual cycles again.2. The antibiotic will not treat STIs unless they are bacterial rather than viral.3. You can start taking antibiotics at any time if you suspect an infection.4. HIV testing should be done immediately after potential exposure.5. Emergency contraception has varying effectiveness depending upon the stage of your cycle. It is usually more effective earlier in the cycle.6. A chemical abortion can be induced by medications, but it is not considered safe.7. Pregnancy tests cannot detect a pregnancy

input: Hello doctor,Three days ago, I fell on my face and cracked my right front tooth right in the middle, horizontally. You cannot see the crack with your bare eyes, but if you shine a light from the back of my tooth, you will see it correctly. It goes from the right to the left, and it stops two millimeters before the next tooth. I was scared, so I asked many dentists before going to an actual appointment myself.They said it was fine, that it is only on the outer layer. Then, I went to an actual dentist myself, and they did an X-ray test on it. Nothing appeared, and said I would be fine, but gave me no further details. I was still left wondering, is there any way the rest of the tooth will fall out eventually because it is very slightly sensitive to change in temperature.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. It is one of the most common complaints in routine dental practice. The fracture (hairline crack) might be only in the superficial structure (more likely in enamel than in dentin) of the tooth and not in the pulp (since it does not hurt). It requires minimal attention, and no specific care is mandatory. You may use desensitizing gel (with potassium nitrate) for brushing and also for a massage before having hot, cold, sweet, and sour stuff. I hope it helps.
answer_chatgpt: As an AI language model, I am unable to give medical advice, diagnose conditions or provide treatment options. However, I suggest you follow up with your dentist for a comprehensive dental examination and treatment plan to assess the severity of the crack in your tooth. They may perform additional tests, such as a pulp test or a CT scan, to determine the extent of the damage and whether further treatment is needed. Sensitivity to temperature changes may indicate nerve involvement or the presence of a crack extending deeper into the tooth, which can lead to more extensive damage if left untreated. Your dentist can recommend various treatment options, such as bonding, veneers, or crowns, to restore the tooth's function and appearance. It is essential to address dental issues promptly to avoid further complications and maintain good oral health.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) The crack in the tooth is not visible by naked eye and can only be detected using special instruments.2) The crack is not extending into the pulp tissue and therefore is not causing any sensitivity.3) The crack is just superficial and does not extend below the enamel or into the inner layers of the tooth.4) No treatment is required at this point except for regular checkups every 6 months.5) If you have any pain or discomfort, you should visit your dentist immediately for evaluation. Hope this helps.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 29 year old married female. I delivered my baby a year ago. I had post-spinal headache for three days in the hospital. Again, for the last eight months, I have been suffering with severe upper shoulder pain, neck pain and one-sided headache. It started with severe giddiness and nausea. I have consulted many neuro physicians and they prescribed me medicines for migraine along with antidepressants. But, I did not get any relief.A neurosurgeon told me to take Dolo for three weeks and Stalopam 10 mg. That too, did not help me. I got my MRI scan done and was diagnosed to have a small cyst (subependymoma) in my head, which doctors said as non-cancerous and not related to these headaches. I lifted heavy weights in my fourth month after my delivery and I had upper shoulder pain.Later, my neck and head pain started. I guess, pain in my upper shoulder muscle leads to neck pain and headache. Doctors say it as a migraine, but I am not sensitive to light. I started taking Vasograin since five days and feeling good for about 80%. Please help to come out of this terrible headache and muscle pain.
answer_icliniq: Hi. We are here to help you. You seem to be suffering from fibromyalgia (muscle pain and fatigue) Fibromyalgia can be associated with migraine headache that presents with one-sided headache. Also, following delivery, females do get these kind of pains and headache due to breastfeeding has led to vitamin D and calcium deficiency causing such pains. Now, I would recommend in such case a test for vitamin D and iron profile. Treatment recommendations would be Amitriptyline and Duloxetine for pain. Vitamin D and iron can be added later based on the reports.  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
I am sorry to hear about your persistent pain and headaches. It sounds like you have been through a lot, including multiple consultations with neuro physicians and a neurosurgeon, and a diagnosis of a non-cancerous cyst that is not believed to be related to your headaches.

Based on your description, it is possible that your pain and headaches are related to muscle tension and/or trigger points in your upper shoulder and neck, as lifting heavy weights can strain these muscles and cause referred pain to the head. Migraine can also be associated with neck pain and muscle tension, even if you are not sensitive to light. Vasograin, which contains a combination of medications that can help relieve headache pain and improve blood flow, may be helpful in managing your symptoms.

In addition to medication, there are other strategies you can try to alleviate your pain and headaches. These include:

- Practicing good posture and ergonomics to reduce strain on your neck and shoulders
- Doing gentle neck and shoulder stretches and exercises to improve mobility and reduce muscle tension
- Applying heat or cold packs to the affected areas
- Trying relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation
- Engaging in regular physical activity to improve overall fitness and relieve stress

It may also be worth seeking out the advice of a physical therapist or a pain management specialist who can provide targeted treatments and techniques to address your specific pain and headache symptoms.

I hope you find relief soon and can return to living your life without constant pain and discomfort. Best of luck in your journey towards optimal health.
answer_chatdoctor: 1. Subependymomas are benign tumors that occur in the brain, usually in the area around the fourth ventricle, where there is an opening between the third and fourth ventricles called the foramen magnum. They can cause symptoms such as headache, vomiting, seizures or changes in vision. Some subependymomas may be associated with cancer.2. The treatment of choice for most subependymomas is surgery.3. The other possibility is that your headache could be due to some sort of cervical spondylosis/ degenerative disc disease causing compression of the nerves in the neck region leading to referred pain in the head.4. You should see a Neurologist who will examine you thoroughly and look at your MRI scan. He might need to refer you to a Neurosurgeon for clinical examination & review of MRI. Hope this helps.

input: Hello doctor,My partner and I had unprotected sex four days from her period and she had taken the Unwanted 72 two days later. So I do not see any reason for you to worry as there is no chance of egg meeting sperms. But as she had an emergency pill, the hormone progesterone pill, the balance would have got disturbed. Usually, she will have the bleeding with thick dark blood seven to 10 days of the pill. Having a bleed after the pill means the inner lining of the uterus has gone. So, there is no chance of pregnancy. Maybe some more bleeding is expected. So, there is a pain in the lower abdominal area. Next period will be one month after this bleeding. For more information consult an infertility specialist online

If your partner continues to experience severe abdominal pain or abnormal bleeding, she should see a doctor for evaluation to rule out any underlying medical conditions or infections.

To prevent future unplanned pregnancies and reduce the risk of STIs, it is important to use barrier methods of contraception such as condoms and get tested regularly for STIs. Your partner can also consider starting a regular form of contraception such as the birth control pill or an IUD after consulting with a healthcare provider.

It could be that there was some delay in ovulation or conception this month.2) If you have regular cycles (28-30 days long), then you can expect your next period around the 25th of August.3) If your periods were irregular, then you may not get it by 25th August.4) In either case, you should take a home pregnancy test after missing one period.5) If the result is negative, you can wait for your period to come & start taking folic acid tablets.6) If the result is positive, the best thing to do would be to terminate the pregnancy.

input: Hello doctor,I had a root canal done in one of my lower right teeth. It was done in one sitting with the help of a laser. Everything was fine for a week. Then, one day my right jaw started aching and I was not able to open the jaw more than half an inch. There wa mild pain below the ear and it increased while chewing.My dentist says it is spasm and it has nothing to do with RCT (root canal treatment). I am taking Flexon MR and doing few muscle exercises keeping the jaw in movement.What is the solution?How long will it take to heal?I am worried will it become permanent?
answer_icliniq: Hello. Yes, it can be due to muscle spasm but as it started after one week then it can also be due to infection in the root canal treated tooth. So, first of all, the exact cause needs to be ruled out. If Flexon MR (Ibuprofen, Paracetamol, and Chlorzoxazone) and muscle exercises are not resolving the problem then an X-ray of the tooth should be done to check for any infection. It can heal mostly within a week. No, it cannot become permanent and both conditions - infection and muscle spasm are treatable. For more information consult a dentist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

It is possible that the pain and limited jaw movement you are experiencing is due to a muscle spasm unrelated to your root canal treatment. This is usually caused by muscle tension or strain in the jaw area, which can lead to discomfort and difficulty opening the mouth.

The treatment you are currently receiving is appropriate, including taking Flexon MR and doing a few muscle exercises. You should continue this and also try to avoid overusing the muscles in the jaw area, such as chewing gum, constant talking or yelling. Additionally, you can use warm compresses to help reduce muscle tension and ease pain.

A muscle spasm usually resolves on its own within a few days to a week. However, in some cases, it may take longer to heal. If your symptoms persist for more than a week or become more severe, its best to consult your dentist or doctor again for further evaluation and treatment.

Finally, it is important to note that it is unlikely for this to become a permanent problem. With proper care and treatment, the muscle spasm should resolve completely.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum.  As you have undergone Root Canal Treatment, the cause of your problem can be either due to the procedure or due to any other reason. The most common cause of problem after the root canal would be due to the infection around the root tip called as Periapical Abscess. This usually occurs if there is an incomplete removal of the infected tissue during the course of treatment. You should consult a Dentist and get the radiograph taken along with a clinical examination. Your symptoms may be due to some infection around the root tip which needs to be treated by means of antibiotics and surgery. Hope this helps you. Regards

You have not mentioned whether the test was done after the expected date of periods. The earliest time for confirmation of pregnancy by urine pregnancy test is after 10 days of missed periods. input: Hi doctor,My LMP was on the 29th of the last month. On 2nd and 3rd this month, I had a mild spotting and on 4th, I got my periods as usual. What can be the reason for the spotting and delay as I have not got this kind of spotting before?

Hello,

There can be several reasons for spotting before the period or between periods. Some of the most common reasons include:

1. Hormonal Imbalance: Fluctuations in hormones can cause changes in the menstrual cycle, leading to spotting.

2. Stress: Emotional or physical stress can cause hormonal changes that affect the menstrual cycle.

3. Birth Control: Some forms of birth control can cause spotting between periods.

4. Pregnancy: Implantation bleeding can cause spotting during early pregnancy.

5. Infections: Infections, such as yeast infections or sexually transmitted infections, can cause spotting.

6. Polyps or Fibroids: Noncancerous growths in the uterus can cause spotting.

7. Thyroid Problems: Thyroid problems can cause hormonal imbalances that affect the menstrual cycle.

If you continue to experience irregular bleeding or spotting, it is important to speak with your healthcare provider to determine the underlying cause and seek appropriate treatment if necessary.

Please consult gynecologist for proper evaluation and management.

input: Hi doctor,My partner is pregnant with twins of 22 weeks. She has kell antigens in her blood received from a transfusion when my first son is born. I did a blood test last week, and I also have a kell group present in my blood. Do my babies are safe? What can be done to help them? Are there any permanent effects that would inhibit them from having a healthy life? I am scared after knowing it. Please help me.
answer_icliniq: Hi. Kell blood group is a minor blood group system. ABO and Rh are called major blood group system. Kell antigen can be antigenic and can create a problem during a blood transfusion or else it may not create any problem. So there is no need for having a specific treatment. Whenever your child requires a blood transfusion, the blood bank should find the right blood suitable for your child as per cross match report. Please mention the blood group of your partner and first child. If the mother is Rh negative and the child is Rh positive, then there is a chance to have a hemolytic disease of a newborn, and it requires anti D.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Thank you for reaching out to me for help. I understand that this can be scary and overwhelming for you, but please know that there are steps that can be taken to help ensure the safety of your babies.

Kell incompatibility occurs when a mother has antibodies to the Kell blood group antigen, which can harm the fetus who has inherited the Kell antigen from the father. It can cause hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN), a condition that can lead to anemia, jaundice, and in severe cases, neurological damage or even stillbirth.

Having a Kell group present in your blood means that there's a chance that you can pass the Kell antigen to your babies. The good news is that since your partner has already received a transfusion, she has likely built up antibodies that can protect your babies from HDFN.

However, it's still important to monitor the babies' health closely throughout the pregnancy. Your partner will need to have regular ultrasounds to check for signs of anemia and other complications. If the babies develop HDFN, they may need treatment such as intrauterine transfusions or early delivery.

The long-term effects for babies affected by HDFN can vary depending on the severity of the condition. Some may have no lasting effects, while others may have developmental delays or other complications. It's important to work closely with your healthcare provider to manage the condition and minimize any potential risks.

In summary, it is important that your partner receive proper medical care throughout the pregnancy and monitor the health of the babies closely. Your healthcare provider will recommend appropriate measures if the babies develop HDFN. With careful management, it's possible for your babies to have a healthy life.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Kell group is an autoimmune disease which affects the red blood cells. This means that your body is producing antibodies against these antigens, which may attack the red blood cells of your children. However, as this is not a serious condition, it does not cause any long-term damage to the fetus or child. 2) The best way to avoid the problem is to receive blood from someone who doesn't have the antigen. You should get tested for other groups, such as Rhesus (Rh), Duffy, MNS, C, E, Kidd, etc., as well as the Kell group. 3) If you do happen to have the same antigen, then you will need to get immunoglobulin therapy during labor. 4) Regardless of what your blood type is, you should always use Rh positive blood when donating plasma or platelets.

input: Hello doctor,About a month ago, I developed what I thought was a pinched nerve in my neck. I had numbing and tingling in my left arm and my hand would go numb while sleeping. Now, these symptoms have mostly left my arms other than occasional slight sensation in my fingers. However, my legs and left foot continue to have this sensation. I do not have any pain other than the sensation and can move normally. However, exerting myself seems to elevate the sensation. I visited my doctor and they ran a complete set of lab work and everything was normal other than slightly low vitamin D. Also scheduled to MRI on the spine to rule out MS. After doing some reading, I think I developed a case of peripheral neuropathy. My question is could this be something else? Is it possible that with rest it will go away? Are there any supplements I could take to help? Any other thoughts or suggestions?

MS (multiple sclerosis) would be an exceptional diagnosis at your age. Vitamin D deficiency may lead to muscle twitching and also joint pain, associated with chronic fatigue. As it resulted low, it is necessary to take vitamin D supplements. I would also like to know if you checked vitamin B12 levels and thyroid hormone levels. Vitamin B12 deficiency can mimic this clinical situation. Regarding peripheral neuropathy, I would recommend performing a nerve conduction study (electroneurography) to exclude this possibility, although it is really less likely that you suffer from this disorder. Hope you will find this answer helpful. For more information consult a neurologist online

Resting may help alleviate some of the symptoms, but it is important to determine the underlying cause to prevent the progression of the condition. Additionally, there are supplements such as B complex vitamins, alpha-lipoic acid, and omega-3 fatty acids that may help. However, it is important to speak with your doctor before starting any supplements to determine if they are safe for you and will not interact with your current medications or underlying medical conditions. 

Overall, it is important to follow up with your doctor and undergo further testing to determine the underlying cause of your symptoms and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

1. Pinch the nostrils together: When a nosebleed occurs, pinch the soft part of the nose (the lower part). Pinching forces pressure on the bleeding point and helps control the bleeding.

2. Lean forward: Leaning forward allows the blood to drain out of the nostrils and not down the back of your child's throat.

3. Apply an ice pack: Applying a cold compress can help constrict the blood vessels and slow down the bleeding.

4. Avoid nose-picking: Encourage your child not to pick their nose or blow their nose forcefully.

If the nosebleed continues for 20 minutes or more, or if it occurs more than once a week, you should consult a doctor for further evaluation. They may prescribe a nasal spray or suggest a cauterization procedure to stop the bleeding.

input: Hi doctor,I asked my doctor to do PSA test. The PSA came back normal at 1.0 ng/mL. However, he also did prostatic acid phosphatase test which was high at 4.5 ng/mL. My question is whether prostatic acid phosphatase test is valid for screening or not? Should I need to do these tests again? I had prostatitis symptoms in the past. Now, it seems to be fine.
answer_icliniq: Hi. I have gone through your query. Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) has been replaced by PSA (prostate-specific antigen test). It is better in the detection of prostate cancer compared to PAP. The elevation of PAP levels alone is not a cause for concern. I hope your treating doctor has done a rectal exam to find out any prostate nodules. If it is normal, then it is not necessary to repeat the tests. Hope this helps you. Feel free to revert back with any questions. For more information consult an urologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) is an enzyme produced by prostate cells, and elevated levels can suggest prostate cancer. However, elevated PAP levels can also be caused by non-cancerous conditions, such as prostatitis, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), or recent ejaculation. It is not commonly used as a screening test for prostate cancer.

A normal PSA test result is usually reassuring, but elevated PAP levels merit further investigation. Considering your history of prostatitis, it is possible that the elevated PAP levels are due to a previous infection. However, your doctor may recommend repeating the test after a few weeks to monitor any changes in the PAP levels. Further evaluation, such as a prostate biopsy, may also be recommended to rule out any underlying prostate cancer. It is best to discuss your concerns and any further steps with your doctor.
answer_chatdoctor: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP) are both enzymes that are found in the prostate gland. PSA is produced by the epithelial cells of the prostate gland and is released into the bloodstream. It can be detected in the blood as early as five years before any clinical signs of prostate cancer appear. PAP is produced by the smooth muscle cells of the prostate gland and is released into the semen. Elevated levels of PAP may indicate inflammation or obstruction of the prostate ducts. It is not a routine test but is sometimes used to monitor patients with prostate problems such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

1. Triptans: These are migraine-specific medications that can help relieve symptoms such as pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound. They work by narrowing blood vessels in the brain. Triptans can be taken as pills, injections, or nasal sprays.

2. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen, aspirin, and naproxen can also help relieve migraine symptoms. These medications work by reducing inflammation.

3. Preventive medications: If you have frequent migraines, your healthcare provider may recommend taking a preventive medication daily to reduce the frequency and severity of your migraines. There are many different types of preventive medications available, including antidepressants, beta blockers, anticonvulsants, and Botox injections.

4. Lifestyle changes: In addition to medication, there are several lifestyle changes you can make to help prevent migraines. These include getting regular exercise, eating a healthy diet, staying hydrated, and getting enough sleep.

It's important to talk to your healthcare provider about your specific symptoms and medical history to determine the best treatment plan for you.

Hi there, I'm sorry to hear that you are struggling. Social phobia, also known as social anxiety disorder, can be a difficult condition to deal with on your own, but the good news is that it's highly treatable. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Seek professional help. It sounds like your social phobia is affecting your quality of life, so it's worth seeking professional help. A mental health professional, such as a therapist or psychiatrist, can provide you with the tools and techniques you need to overcome your anxiety.

2. Try relaxation techniques. Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation can be helpful in managing anxiety. These techniques can help you calm down when you feel anxious.

3. Challenge your negative thoughts. Your negative thoughts may be fueling your anxiety. Learning to recognize and challenge these thoughts can help you feel less anxious in social situations.

4. Practice social skills. Social skills are like any other skill - they require practice to get better. Start small by striking up a conversation with someone you feel comfortable around, like a friend or family member, and gradually work your way up to more challenging social situations.

5. Consider medication. In some cases, medication may be helpful in treating social phobia. Talk to your doctor or mental health professional about whether medication might be right for you.

Remember, overcoming social phobia takes time and effort, but it's possible. With professional help and support, you can learn to manage your anxiety and live a fulfilling life.

input: Hi doctor,Please explain about the causes of the IBS. How can it be managed? Please advice.
answer_icliniq: Hi. The exact cause of irritable bowel syn ChatDoctor.  The other causes are stress, anxiety, hormone changes, genetic factors, and infections such as salmonella. Treatment depends on the cause. We can do a blood test, hormonal test, coproculture, thyroid function test, colonoscopy, and test for celiac disease to identify the cause. After seeing the results, proper treatment can be planned. Stop taking caffeine and alcohol. Avoid eating fatty foods. Eat a fiber diet. It helps to get relief from constipation.
answer_chatgpt:
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic condition that affects the large intestine. The causes of IBS are not fully understood, but it is believed to be a combination of several factors. Some of these factors include:

1. Changes in the gut microbiome: The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that live in the digestive tract. Changes in the composition or diversity of these microorganisms can contribute to the development of IBS.

2. Food sensitivities: Certain foods can trigger IBS symptoms, particularly FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols). FODMAPs are a group of carbohydrates that are poorly absorbed in the small intestine and can lead to gas, bloating, and diarrhea.

3. Stress and emotional factors: Stress and anxiety can worsen IBS symptoms, and many people with IBS report that their symptoms are triggered by emotional factors.

4. Abnormalities in the nervous system: Abnormalities in the way the brain and the gut communicate with each other can lead to IBS.

5. Muscle contractions in the intestine: Abnormal muscle contractions in the intestine, which can be caused by hormonal imbalances, medications or other factors, can contribute to IBS.

There is no cure for IBS, but it can be effectively managed with lifestyle changes and medication. The management of IBS usually involves diet modification, stress management, regular exercise, and medication. Your doctor may recommend a low-FODMAP diet, which involves avoiding certain foods that are high in FODMAPs. Other dietary interventions may include increasing fiber intake or avoiding certain trigger foods. Stress management techniques like meditation or cognitive-behavioral therapy can also be helpful. Medications such as antispasmodics or laxatives may be prescribed depending on the patient's symptoms. In some cases, psychological therapies such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or hypnotherapy may be recommended for long-term symptom control. Consultation with a gastroenterologist is necessary to guide you through the best treatment options for your specific case.

input: Hello doctor,I did my ECG today in which I got a first-degree atrioventricular block. What does this mean and is this a serious issue? What is its cause and treatment, please?
answer_icliniq: Hello. A first-degree heart block means there is a slight delay in conduction of heart impulse from one chamber to another, that is from atria to ventricles.This is not a serious issue. There are many causes for it, few are, congenital defects in the heart, old age, taking some  ChatDoctor.  If you are having any symptoms then only you should investigate it further, otherwise, do not worry about it. This will decide your treatment. If you are not having any symptoms then do not worry.  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello, first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block is a delay in the electrical conduction of the heart through the AV node, which can be detected on an ECG. It is usually an asymptomatic, benign condition, and does not require any specific treatment. It means that the electrical signal from the upper chamber of the heart (atria) is delayed slightly as it passes through the AV node before it reaches the lower chamber of the heart (ventricles).

The cause of first-degree AV block can vary and may be present in normal individuals without any underlying heart disease. However, it can also occur as a result of certain medications, electrolyte imbalances, metabolic disorders or structural heart issues. If there is an underlying heart disease, like coronary artery disease, hypertension, or myocarditis, it may need to be addressed.

Therefore, if there are any underlying symptoms, medical conditions or abnormalities found during physical examination, additional tests or investigations may be needed to determine the cause of the first-degree AV block. In general, treatment is not required for first-degree AV block, but it is important to monitor any symptoms, and the condition should be followed up with regular appointments with your healthcare provider.
answer_chatdoctor: 1st degree AV block means that there is an interruption of conduction of electrical impulses from your heart to the ventricles (pumping chambers) during each heartbeat cycle. This is caused by a problem with the pathway for these impulses to pass through. It can be either congenital or acquired and may be due to a number of causes including medications, electrolyte imbalances etc. Treatment depends upon the underlying cause. You should consult a cardiologist who will examine you and order tests like EKG, echocardiogram and blood tests along with an exercise stress test if necessary to determine the cause and treatment.

Spinal stenosis is a condition that occurs when the spaces within your spine narrow, causing pressure on your spinal cord and the nerves that travel through it. Depending on the severity of your condition, treatment options may include medication management, physical therapy, and surgery.

In cases where conservative treatments are not effective, a surgical procedure called a decompression laminectomy may be recommended to alleviate pressure on your spinal cord and nerves. During the surgery, your surgeon will remove the part of your vertebra that is compressing your spinal cord or nerves.

It is important to consult with an orthopedic or neurosurgeon who specializes in spinal stenosis to discuss the best treatment option for you. They can evaluate your condition, assess the severity of your symptoms, and recommend a personalized treatment plan tailored to your needs.

- Choose whole grains: Whole grains such as brown rice, quinoa, whole wheat bread, and oatmeal contain soluble fiber that can lower your cholesterol levels.

- Limit intake of processed foods and sugary drinks: Processed foods and sugary drinks are often high in calories, saturated and trans fats, and added sugars which can raise your cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

- Increase intake of healthy fats: Foods such as nuts, seeds, avocados, and fatty fish (salmon, mackerel, and sardines) contain healthy fats that can lower your cholesterol levels.

- Be mindful of your portion sizes: Eating too much of any food can lead to weight gain and elevated cholesterol levels.

I hope this helps you achieve a healthier cholesterol level. It is also recommended to consult with a registered dietitian or healthcare provider to develop personalized dietary guidelines.

Polycystic ovaries are a separate issue, but they can contribute to irregular periods. Adenomyosis diagnosis can be confirmed definitively only by uterine biopsy, but your ultrasound findings suggest atrisk for adenomyosis. 

Treatment for your condition depends on the severity of your symptoms and your desire for future fertility. Hormonal medications such as birth control pills, progesterone, or Gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogues can help alleviate symptoms. Tranexamic acid and mefenamic acid may help to reduce heavy bleeding, but they do not address the underlying cause. In severe cases, hysterectomy (removal of the uterus) may be necessary. You should follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss the best treatment option for your specific condition.

input: Hello doctor,Can you please help me understand my test results? My platelet count is at 1314, and my doctors are unable to give me a specific reason for it.

answer_chatgpt:
Hello! I'd be happy to help. A platelet count of 1314 is extremely high (normal range is typically 150,000 to 450,000 platelets per microliter of blood). This condition is known as thrombocytosis, and it can have several potential causes. Some possible explanations for high platelet counts include:

1. Essential thrombocythemia: This is a rare condition in which the bone marrow produces too many platelets. It can cause blood clots and other complications, and may require treatment.

2. Reactive thrombocytosis: This is a response to another underlying condition, such as an infection or inflammation. In this case, treating the underlying condition should resolve the thrombocytosis.

3. Iron-deficiency anemia: Although this might seem counterintuitive, severe iron-deficiency anemia can lead to an increase in platelet count because the body is trying to compensate for the lack of oxygen-carrying red blood cells.

4. Certain medications: Some medications, such as steroids and epinephrine, can cause an increase in platelet count.

5. Other conditions: There are several other conditions that can cause high platelet counts, including cancer, liver disease, and some autoimmune disorders.

If your doctors are unable to give you a specific reason for your high platelet count, I would recommend seeking a referral to a hematologist (blood specialist). They can perform additional testing and evaluation to determine the cause of your thrombocytosis and develop a treatment plan if necessary.

Based on your description, it seems like you could have a knee injury related to overuse or poor form during exercise. The fact that you felt a cracking sound during jogging or walking is a concerning symptom as it could indicate cartilage damage or wear. The use of leg workouts like squats, leg extension, leg press, and deadlift could also have contributed to your Knee pain.

The medicines your doctor has prescribed can help reduce inflammation and pain. However, it is important to keep in mind that early osteoarthritis can be managed and controlled but may be difficult to cure completely. To manage this issue, you may want to consider the following:

1. Rest: Resting the knee and avoiding activities that aggravate the pain, such as high-impact exercises, is essential to allow healing and recovery.

2. Physical therapy: Working with a physical therapist can help to gradually rebuild strength and flexibility in the knee to prevent further injury.

3. Proper form: Ensure that you are using proper form and technique during exercise to avoid putting unnecessary stress on your knees. A certified personal trainer or physical therapist can help you with this.

4. Weight control: Maintaining a healthy weight can help to reduce the pressure on your knee joints.

5. Consult the doctor: Regular check-ups or visits to the doctor are recommended to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

As for continuing with workouts, it is best to follow your doctor's advice and avoid high-impact activities that could worsen your symptoms. Once your symptoms have subsided, you may be able to gradually resume exercise with the guidance of a physical therapist or trainer.

Lastly, it is important to note that knee pain can be caused by many different factors, such as meniscal tears, ligament sprains, tendinitis, or patellar tracking disorder. Therefore, it is crucial to have a comprehensive evaluation with a doctor and undergo any necessary tests or imaging to determine the underlying cause of your knee pain.

- Challenge negative thoughts and engage in cognitive restructuring to reframe them.
- Avoid excessive use of substances like alcohol or drugs, as these can worsen symptoms over time.

input: Hello doctor, I am 29 years old. Recently they have been sporadic in their comings lasting anywhere from two to seven days with a lighter flow and a change in color with no clotting as used to be normal. I went to my gynecologist after the first incident and as per him, my cervix was soft and sensitive causing me discomfort when applying pressure.My stomach now is still the same with a harder to touch feel with pain in my lower right hip side that radiates up towards the bottom of my ribs lasting seconds to minutes and recurring frequently. It could be possibly a developing ovarian cyst which is duly enlarging in size. Oligo and hypomenorrhea are a feature in such cases. This is definitely not pregnancy. Ovarian cysts are known to produce estrogenic symptoms like sore tender breasts, nausea and bloating sensation as well. The softness of the cervix could be attributed to the same. My advice would be to undergo a pelvic ultrasound at the earliest to rule out right-sided ovarian cyst formation or probably an endometrioma accompanied. The size would further decide the course of treatment. you may contact me for further opinion.  Take care.

Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your shoulder injury. A Hill-Sachs lesion is a defect in the bone of the upper arm bone (humerus) that forms after a shoulder dislocation. Without seeing your MRI images or examining you personally, this is a difficult question to answer. However, here are some general guidelines:

- Rest is critical, and you must follow your doctor's recommended treatment plan. Failure to do so can lead to long-term shoulder instability, pain, and stiffness.
- After being immobilized for six months or so, your physician may request another MRI to see if the Hill-Sachs lesion has healed or progressed. This would be the best way to assess improvement, and your doctor may make further recommendations based on the findings.
- A physical therapist can guide you as to when and how to reintegrate exercise or activity once you become cleared by your doctor. These professionals can provide stretching, strengthening, and range-of-motion exercises tailored to your needs.
- Documenting your progress through a diary or journal, recording any unusual pain or symptoms, can aid in tracking how well the healing process is progressing.

In short, follow your physician's advice and obtain any necessary follow-up appointments or imaging. Then, after clearance, your physical therapist can provide tailored advice as to how to return to your active lifestyle.

1. Use a gentle, fragrance-free soap: Choose a soap that is specifically designed to treat acne, which will help to unclog your pores and prevent new breakouts from forming. Look for one that is oil-free and fragrance-free, as fragrances can irritate your skin and aggravate your acne. Some good brands to try are Neutrogena, Cetaphil, and Dove.

2. Apply a topical acne treatment: There are several over-the-counter treatments that can help to clear up acne, such as benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and alpha hydroxy acids. Apply the product to your back as directed, and avoid using too much or applying it too often, as this can dry out your skin and make your acne worse.

3. Exfoliate gently: Use a gentle exfoliating product once or twice a week to help remove dead skin cells and keep your pores clear. Be gentle with your skin, however, as over-exfoliating can cause irritation and inflammation.

4. Don't pick at your acne: It can be tempting to pick at your acne, but this can make it worse and can lead to scarring. Try to avoid touching your back as much as possible, and if you absolutely must pick at your acne, use clean tools and be gentle.

5. Visit a dermatologist: If your acne is severe or doesn't respond to over-the-counter treatments, it's best to see a dermatologist. They can prescribe stronger medications or recommend other treatments, such as laser therapy.

Overall, acne can be difficult to manage, but with a good skincare routine and some patience, you should be able to get it under control. Good luck!

answer_chatgpt:
Certainly, Lidocaine spray can be helpful in reducing discomfort when wearing a retainer. Here are the steps to properly use Lidocaine spray:

1. Wash your hands thoroughly.

2. Remove your retainer and rinse your mouth with water.

3. Hold the Lidocaine spray bottle upright and remove the cap.

4. Spray the solution onto a cotton swab or a small and clean piece of gauze.

5. Apply the solution to the area beneath your tongue and lower gums where the retainer fits.

6. Wait for 5 minutes before wearing your retainer again.

7. Do not rinse, eat, or drink anything for at least 30 minutes after applying the Lidocaine spray.

It is crucial to use Lidocaine spray in moderation since it can lead to numbness of the mouth and tongue. So, make sure not to overdose or apply it to any other part of your mouth. If you experience any unwanted symptoms or reactions, such as dizziness or difficulty breathing, stop using the spray immediately, and seek medical attention.

Overall, listen to your skin and adjust your washing routine based on how it feels. If it feels dry or irritated, reduce the amount of washing, and if you're experiencing breakouts, consider adding a spot treatment to your routine.

input: Hello doctor,My mom met an accident with a head injury. Right FTP SDH and midline shift, craniectomy surgery is done on the same day. But still she is semi-unconscious. There are body movements, but she has not yet opened her eyes. Ventilator has been removed before 30 hours. I want to know when she can open her eyes and how long will it take to become normal. I have attached a recent CT scan.
answer_icliniq: Hello. This is the most common question we encounter in our daily practice. One thing I want you to understand is that the surgery which has been performed was a \\life-saving procedure\\. If that were not done, we would have lost her; luckily, thank God that did not happen. The rest of the recovery is actually unpredictable. Depending on the extent of the damage, the patient will recover after this sort of surgery. Positive things are she has survived, she is off the ventilator, her injury was more on the right side and not on the left side. So there are pretty good chances that she will improve eventually. If it had been more injury on the left side, we would not have expected her ever to speak again or calculate again. That is not the case with the right side. She would open her eyes in less than a week. Other functions will take time to recover up to six months. The next stage is you have to focus on rehabilitation measures.
answer_chatgpt:
I'm sorry to hear about your mother's accident. Based on the CT scan you have provided, it seems that she has suffered a significant head injury with a right frontal traumatic subdural hematoma and midline shift. The craniectomy surgery is a necessary intervention in such cases. The fact that she is still semi-unconscious and has not opened her eyes after 30 hours is concerning. There are several factors that can affect the time it takes to recover from a traumatic brain injury, including the severity of the injury, the age and overall health of the patient, and the treatment given. 

The first few days after a traumatic brain injury are critical, and it is not uncommon for patients to be in a state of reduced consciousness during this time. It is essential to monitor your mother's condition closely, and the medical team will be doing that. They will also reassess her condition regularly to determine if there are any changes, and if the treatment plan needs to be adjusted. Recovery can take time, and it largely depends on the severity of the injury.

The fact that your mother has body movements is a positive sign. It indicates that her brainstem is functioning, which is responsible for regulating vital functions such as breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure. However, the brainstem alone is not enough to regain full consciousness. The cerebral cortex, which is responsible for conscious thought, perception, and voluntary movement, also needs to recover.

I wish I could give you an exact timeline for when your mother will recover. Unfortunately, it is impossible to predict with certainty. However, the medical team will be doing everything they can to help your mother recover as quickly and safely as possible. It is essential to be patient, and to provide your mother with all the support she needs during this time.
answer_chatdoctor: Hello, Head injuries are very unpredictable. It depends on the severity of the injury that determines the outcome. The brain is very delicate organ and if there is any damage then it takes time for repairing. She may or may not regain consciousness. Also, there may be some other changes in her neurological functioning like loss of sensation etc. You need to consult your treating doctor regarding these issues. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 19 year old boy and I have myopia (2.5 approximately in both the eyes) and I am wearing glasses since two and a half years. Now, I am thinking to quit glasses. What best can I do to reduce the power and quit glasses completely?
answer_icliniq: Hello. Myopia is a refractive error. The change in your refractive correction should be checked every six months to note any progression/improvement. Even a fundus examination is necessary. The refractive correction needed can be given either via spectacles or contact lenses. Giving up on glasses will not help. It can further increase the refractive error. If you are not comfortable with glasses, you could switch to options like contact lenses. For more information consult an eye care ophthalmologist online  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! Unfortunately, there are no proven methods to completely cure myopia or reduce the power of the lenses required. However, there are a few things that you can do to potentially slow down the progression of myopia:

1. Take frequent breaks when reading or using a computer to rest your eyes.

2. Practice good lighting and posture when reading or using a computer.

3. Get regular eye exams to monitor your vision and make sure your glasses prescription is up-to-date.

4. Consider orthokeratology, a non-surgical procedure that uses specially designed contact lenses to reshape the cornea temporarily while you sleep.

It's important to remember that wearing glasses or contact lenses is not a bad thing and can be necessary for maintaining good vision. If you're looking to quit glasses for cosmetic reasons, consider speaking with an optometrist or ophthalmologist to discuss your options further.
answer_chatdoctor: Thank you for posting your query. Myopia is an inherited condition which cannot be cured by any treatment. But if you wear glasses or contact lenses, it will help improve vision. The progression of myopia slows down after puberty and stabilizes at around age 20. So, if you stop wearing glasses, there will not be much change in your refractive error. However, if you do not want to wear spectacles, then you could go for surgical correction like LASIK or PRK. These surgeries remove tissue from the cornea to correct refractive errors. You need to consult an ophthalmologist for detailed evaluation before proceeding with such procedures. Hope this helps.
