input: Hi doctor,I am now seven weeks pregnant. The issue is my hCG at 18 DPO was 664, and then at 22 DPO was 2002, and then a week after the last measure, it was 3900 (different lab). It has not doubled properly. I had a scan at 6 weeks 3 days approx. and fetus measuring around 5 mm with HR of 120, was told its good and measured 6 weeks. Do I still have a chance at a normal pregnancy or will I miscarry due to hCG not doubling as they should?
answer_icliniq: Hello There is a good chance that you may continue the pregnancy, simply because the initial doubling of hCG from 664 to 2002 was evident and indicated adequate placentation. Ideally, the serum beta hCG levels should rise by 63 to 65 % in 46 hours. So, as can be seen, that they are and to add further, the fetal heart rate has arrived. The heart rate is low with known standards (140-160 bpm), but nevertheless, this is an ongoing pregnancy and you should be placed on Progesterone support for the next four weeks to allow better placentation. You may get a repeat scan done after two weeks to check for fetal viability and growth.  Regards. For more information consult an obstetrician and gynaecologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Congratulations on your pregnancy! While hCG levels can be useful in monitoring early pregnancy, it's important to know that they can vary greatly between individual women and also within the same woman from pregnancy to pregnancy.

A lack of doubling hCG levels is not always a sign of impending miscarriage. In fact, there are many cases where the levels of hCG do not double as expected, but the pregnancy progresses just fine. The further along you are in the pregnancy, the less accurate hCG levels are for determining pregnancy viability.

Your ultrasound scan is a good sign, as a fetal heartbeat at 6 weeks is an excellent indicator of a viable pregnancy. As long as there are no other concerning signs, such as vaginal bleeding or cramping, there is no reason to assume that the pregnancy is not viable.

I would recommend following up with your healthcare provider for any additional testing or follow-up that they may recommend. Ultimately, time and monitoring will provide a greater understanding of your pregnancy outcome.

input: Hello doctor,I am implanted with a pacemaker. I am aged 71, potassium 5.1, fasting glucose 273, postprandial 353. What diet should I follow?
answer_icliniq: Hello. It needs to be monitored very strictly with diet so that it will help to manage the present condition and avoid kidney problems. Strictly follow a diabetic diet plan with complex carbohy ChatDoctor.  Avoid excess potassium-rich foods like greens, citrus, tender coconut water, ragi in diet till potassium is under control. You can include fruits like apple, pineapple, and guava in diet approximately 100 g per day.  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Based on the laboratory results you provided, it appears that you have hyperglycemia or high blood sugar levels. It is essential to consume a low-carbohydrate diet to control glucose levels. A diet with low carbohydrate intake will also promote weight loss and benefit the heart.

Here are some dietary guidelines for you to follow:

1. Consume complex carbohydrates: Choose complex carbohydrates such as whole grains, legumes, and vegetables that are low in sugar as they are digested slowly and do not cause a sharp rise in blood sugar levels.

2. Avoid simple carbohydrates: Avoid foods that contain high amounts of sugar like candy, soda, baked goods, and processed foods as they may cause a rapid increase in blood sugar levels.

3. Eat more fiber: Consume dietary fiber from fruits, vegetables, and legumes because it promotes healthy digestion, manages weight, and improves glucose control.

4. Choose healthy fats: Consume healthy fats such as nuts, seeds, olive oil, and avocados, which can help lower cholesterol and are good for heart health.

5. Limit sodium intake: Limit your intake of sodium-rich foods to reduce the risk of high blood pressure and swelling, especially if you have heart disease.

6. Hydration: Drink plenty of water and consume non-sugary fluids such as herbal teas, coffee or milk.

If an enlarged adenoid gland is causing symptoms, treatment options may include:

1. Antibiotics  If the swelling is due to an infection, antibiotics may be prescribed to treat it.
2. Nasal steroid sprays  These can help reduce inflammation and swelling around the adenoids.
3. Adenoidectomy  If the adenoids are causing significant symptoms, surgery may be necessary to remove them.

The treatment will depend on the severity of the symptoms and the underlying cause of the adenoid enlargement. You should discuss your symptoms with your doctor who can advise you on the best course of action.

1. Poor oral hygiene habits: Poor oral hygiene can lead to bad breath. So, maintain good oral hygiene practices like brushing your teeth twice a day, flossing, and scraping your tongue.

2. Dry mouth: Dry mouth is another cause of bad breath. When there is a lack of saliva production in your mouth, it leads to dryness and promotes the growth of bacteria. Drinking plenty of water and chewing sugarless gum can help to keep your mouth moist.

3. Gum disease: Gum disease is an infection that occurs in your gum tissue, which causes bad breath. Regular dental check-ups and cleanings can prevent gum disease.

4. Sinus and throat infections: Bad breath can also be a result of a sinus or throat infection. You may need to see your primary care provider for appropriate treatment.

5. Health problems: Some medical conditions like diabetes, liver disease, and acid reflux can cause bad breath.

It would help if you consulted with your dentist or primary care provider to identify the root cause of your bad breath. They may recommend certain tests and treatments, depending on the underlying cause.

answer_chatgpt: Beta thalassemia trait is usually considered a mild condition that doesn't cause any serious medical complications. It occurs when a person inherits one copy of the beta thalassemia gene from one parent and a normal gene from the other parent. People with beta thalassemia trait usually have fewer red blood cells than normal, which may cause mild anemia or fatigue. However, they usually don't require any specific medical treatment for this condition. It's important to note that beta thalassemia major or intermedia, which occur when both copies of the beta thalassemia gene are mutated, are much more serious conditions that may require regular blood transfusions and other medical management.

A child with beta-thalassemia trait may have mild to severe symptoms like fatigue, pallor, weakness, rapid heart rate, etc. So I advise you to get yourself tested for the same. You should avoid marrying someone who has beta-thalassemia trait as your child may inherit the disorder from you.

1. Behavioral techniques: One common approach is to try behavioral techniques, such as the "squeeze technique" or the "start-stop" technique. These techniques involve interrupting sexual activity before ejaculation and using a specific technique to help control the timing of ejaculation.

2. Medications: There are several medications available that are designed to help with premature ejaculation. These include topical creams, such as lidocaine, and oral medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).

3. Counseling: Counseling can be useful in helping to address underlying psychological issues that may be contributing to premature ejaculation. Anxiety, depression, and relationship issues can all impact sexual performance.

input: Hello doctor,Avascular necrosis was caused by a slipped capital femoral epiphysis of the left hip in a 12-year-old girl. What is the treatment apart from hip replacement? I need help. My daughter is in the middle of a bridge.

The treatment for avascular necrosis depends on several factors such as the extent of the disease, location of the affected bone, severity of symptoms, and age of the patient.

Apart from hip replacement, there are several nonoperative treatment options available for avascular necrosis of the hip, including:

1. Medications: Certain medications such as bisphosphonates can reduce bone loss and improve bone density, thereby reducing the progression of avascular necrosis.

2. Rest and weight-bearing restrictions: Resting the affected joint and restricting weight-bearing activities can prevent further damage to the bone.

3. Physical therapy: Physical therapy can help to improve joint function, flexibility, and strength.

4. Electrical stimulation therapy: This therapy uses electrical currents to stimulate the growth of new bone tissue.

5. Core decompression: This procedure involves drilling into the affected bone to relieve pressure and improve blood flow to the area.

It is essential to consult with a medical professional to determine the best treatment option for your daughter's condition. They can also advise you on the appropriate rehabilitation and lifestyle changes necessary to manage the disease.

Then I got vaccinated for rubella to prevent any casualties in the next pregnancy. Now I want to try and conceive, but just now I got my torch panel done again. And now the HSV IGM is positive with 1.15 range along with CMV and rubella IgG positive. Should I wait or can I try to conceive right now? My husband\s torch panel also done, nothing abnormal.I am currently under Folic acid and Multivitamin, for now, to conceive faster. And also a homeopathic medicine for migraine.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Yes, you can try for your pregnancy as IgG (immunoglobulin G) means that you do not have any current infection. It is only due to prior exposure. And for HSV, the only thing you have to watch is the presence of active lesions. Otherwise, there is no other reason not to try for pregnancy. You must try for it whenever you and your partner feel ready to do so. answer_chatgpt:
Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your previous silent missed abortion, and I understand that you are concerned about your Torch panel results.

First, let me explain the Torch panel. It is a blood test that checks for several infections that can impact a pregnancy. The test includes four main components: Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus (CMV), and Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).

I can see that your previous test showed that you were positive for CMV IgG. This means that you have been exposed to the virus in the past and that your body has developed antibodies against it. A positive IgG result is generally not a concern in pregnancy.

Regarding Rubella, I'm glad to see that you were vaccinated after your previous abortion. This will help protect you and your future fetus from Rubella.

Now coming to your current HSV IgM result, I must say that it is of concern. IgM antibodies typically indicate a recent HSV infection, and in the context of trying to conceive, this could be risky. HSV infection during pregnancy can cause problems such as neonatal herpes, which can be severe or even deadly in some cases.

However, it's important to keep in mind that HSV IgM results can be a false-positive. This means that the test may show an incorrect positive result. To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor may recommend further testing.

In the meantime, it's essential to use safe sex practices to reduce the risk of transmitting the virus to your partner. Also, please consult with your healthcare provider about the proper next steps and what this test result could mean for your future pregnancy.

Finally, please continue taking folic acid and a multivitamin to prepare and support a healthy pregnancy. I hope this information helps!

input: Hello doctor,I am suffering from follicles on legs from six months it is non-itchy and painless, and when I apply any cream Clop-G it becomes tiny, and after stopping the cream becomes as usual, and from six months, I saw a minor change in the increase or decrease in size. Hello!

Follicles are normal structures found in our skin. They are small sacs that contain the hair root. However, these structures can become inflamed and result in a condition called folliculitis.

Folliculitis commonly appears as tiny red bumps or white pus-filled pimples around the hair follicles. It can be caused by bacteria, fungi, or viruses that infect the hair follicle.

The use of topical corticosteroids such as Clop-G can cause temporary improvement but is not a definitive treatment for folliculitis. In fact, long-term use of topical corticosteroids may worsen the condition.

To treat folliculitis, it is important to identify the underlying cause. You may need to consult a dermatologist to confirm the diagnosis and to determine the best course of action. The treatment options may include:

- Topical or oral antibiotics to combat bacterial infection
- Antifungal medication to treat fungal infection
- Topical or oral antiviral medication for viral infection
- Laser hair removal to prevent recurrences due to ingrown hairs
- Keeping the skin clean and dry and avoiding tight clothing
- Avoiding shaving or using a clean razor if necessary
- Using warm compresses to reduce inflammation

Make sure to follow proper hygiene practices and avoid sharing personal items such as towels and razors to prevent the spread of infection.

I hope this helps!

input: Hello doctor,I had a hip X-ray of 35 mAs. An average hip x-ray is supposed to be 20 mAs/.07 mSv. So if my hip x-ray was 35 mAs, how many more mSv have I received? Was I overexposed?
answer_icliniq: Hello. The x-ray power output depends on mAs (milliampere-seconds) and kVp (kilovoltage peak) parameters. The average hip x-ray can be done at about 20 to 30 mAs and 70 to 80 KVp. The general rule is that the percentage increase in mAs causes a similar increase in radiation dose. In your case we can take the average tube current as 25 mAs and dose given to you is 35 mAs. Therefore you might have received 30 to 40 percent over the dose if given a 25 mAs exposure. As x-ray dose for hip x-ray is less when talking about the harmful effects of radiation, so you do not have any significant increase in radiation dose risks.
answer_chatgpt:
The relationship between mAs and dose is not linear, so it is difficult to estimate the exact dose received without more information about the machine used and the technique factors. However, in general, increasing the mAs by 15 units (from average of 20 mAs to 35 mAs) would increase the radiation dose by approximately 50% (from 0.07 mSv to 0.10 mSv).

This increase in dose may not necessarily be considered an overexposure, as the maximum permissible dose for a single X-ray examination is much higher (typically around 20 mSv) and the actual risk of harm from a single diagnostic X-ray examination is generally low. 

Nevertheless, it is important to limit the radiation dose as much as possible, so it is recommended to use the lowest effective dose required to obtain the necessary diagnostic information. Your doctor or radiologist may be able to give you more information about the risks and benefits of the examination and the specific dose you received.
answer_chatdoctor: 35mAs is equal to 184 mRads. The amount of radiation exposure from a chest x-ray (for example) varies depending on the size of the image and the thickness of the body part being imaged. For a frontal chest x-ray, the estimated effective dose is about 0.19 millisieverts (mSv). This means that for every 100 chest x-rays done, the person receiving them would receive an average of 19 mSv of radiation.

In your son's case, since he had an extra heart beat and his troponin levels were slightly elevated, it may indicate that he experienced some mild heart muscle injury. Usually, the treatment for elevated troponin levels is based on treating the underlying cause of the heart injury. Depending on the severity of the injury, the doctor may prescribe rest, medication or other treatments to help stabilize the heart muscle.

It is important to follow-up with your son's doctor for further evaluation and management of his condition. They may also refer him to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and testing if needed.

Hello! A wide midline maxillary diastema can be corrected with orthodontic treatment, usually with braces or clear aligners. The treatment duration may vary depending on the severity of the gap and the patient's age, but typically takes anywhere from 6 months to 2 years.

In the case of missing lateral incisors, there are a few options for closing the gap. One option is to move the adjacent teeth to close the space, which can be done with orthodontics. Another option is to replace the missing teeth with dental implants or bridges. 

The chances of relapse depend on several factors, including the severity of the diastema, the type of orthodontic treatment used, and the patient's oral hygiene habits. It is important to maintain good oral hygiene to avoid relapse, which may include wearing retainers after treatment and visiting your dentist regularly for cleanings and check-ups.

Overall, with proper treatment and maintenance, a wide midline maxillary diastema can be effectively corrected and maintained with a low risk of relapse.

Currently, they are based on the ADA recommendations.Carbohydrates 40 % / 179 g, protein 35 % / 157 g and fat 25 % / 50 g. I also have high blood pressure. I am on 100 mg Losartan, and my reading today was 117/84/77 bpm. Kindly help.

Based on the information, you provided, you should be on medication from my experience, like low dose Metformin 500 mg twice daily with meals, or Metformin 500 mg. Extended-release once daily. While you work on diet and exercise, this is help also prevent complication from diabetes. Metformin will help you lose weight too. Metformin also improves your insulin work better for you for better and quick control of blood sugar. 2. You can check blood sugar three times weekly, at different times. E.g., one-day fasting (before breakfast, second-day post-lunch, and third day at bedtime. (2 hours post-dinner). Keep diary readings. However, you prefer to see the trend of your blood sugar. Normal range fasting in the morning 90 to 120. Post-meal 120-140 average is good. I recommend a high protein, low carbohy ChatDoctor.  You are in more top weight category so surely gradually need to lose weight, do not attempt instant aggressive weight loss you will end up injuring yourself and will regain weight too. I would keep carbohy
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! It is great that you are taking proactive steps to manage your diabetes. Here are some answers to your questions: 

Blood glucose monitoring: 
You should monitor your blood glucose levels based on your doctor's recommendations. Typically, it is recommended to test your blood glucose: 
- Upon waking up in the morning (fasting blood glucose) 
- Before meals 
- 2 hours after meals 

Target blood glucose ranges: 
- Fasting blood glucose: Less than 100 mg/dL 
- Pre-meal blood glucose: 70-130 mg/dL 
- Post-meal blood glucose: Less than 180 mg/dL 

However, these target ranges may vary based on your individual health goals, and your doctor can provide more specific recommendations. 

Daily carbohydrate intake: 
Your daily carbohydrate intake should be determined based on your individual nutritional needs and health goals. However, the general recommendation for individuals with diabetes is to aim for 45-60 grams of carbohydrates per meal, and 15-30 grams of carbohydrates per snack. This can help with blood glucose management and prevent spikes. 

As for the breakdown of macronutrients (carbohydrates, protein, and fat), the ADA recommends the following for individuals with diabetes: 
- Carbohydrates: 45-60% of total daily calories 
- Protein: 15-20% of total daily calories 
- Fat: 25-35% of total daily calories 

However, these percentages may vary based on your individual health goals and nutritional needs. Working with a registered dietitian can help you develop a personalized meal plan based on your preferences and health goals. 

Lastly, it's great that you are managing your blood pressure with Losartan. Aim to keep your blood pressure below 130/80 mmHg to reduce the risk of complications associated with diabetes. Keep up the great work, and best of luck on your journey!
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, thanks for writing in. You said your BP is normal and so there is no need for any change in your medicines as yet. Your HbA1c is quite good and so you do not require insulin or other medicines at this time. However, it would be wise to keep a close watch on your blood sugars to make sure that they remain under control. Please get your blood sugars checked once every week initially and then once every two weeks till your HbA1c falls below 6%. This may take 3-4 months. After that, you can check once a month. As regards diet, you must have 3 meals a day with regular snacks. You can eat all fruits, vegetables, pulses, sprouts and meat (chicken) without restriction. Do not have rice or potatoes more than once a day. Have some physical activity like walking briskly for 30 minutes

Taking two doses of emergency contraception (Unwanted 72) within 24 hours provides highly effective protection against pregnancy, even if there was a break in the condom. The negative pregnancy test and the ultrasound report that shows an endometrial thickness of 4 mm further suggest that you are not pregnant. In early pregnancy, the endometrial lining tends to be thickened, typically measuring around 10 mm or more.

It's reasonable to start taking your regular birth control pills again, though it's important to use additional contraceptive protection (such as condoms) for at least the first seven days. The advice to wait until your next period to restart the pills is a common recommendation, as it can help to ensure that you start the pills at the optimal time for contraception.

It's possible that the timing of your next period may be slightly different after taking emergency contraception and restarting birth control pills, but it's generally not a cause for concern.

input: Hi doctor,I do a couple of sports to have some hip flexibility. I am pretty flexible, and I can do right and left splits. But when doing the center split, I get a stopping pain in my outer hip with no stretch in my inner thigh. If I rotate my knees back and hips forward, I can do more stretch, but there is also a slight stop. What is this and can it be worked? Will stretching help to release that stopping pain or am I anatomically incapable of doing a middle split? There is pain only when I am doing a center split. How to fix it? I do a lot of kicking, and I do not want to injure myself.
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. There are many factors, other than tight inner thigh muscles that limit the split especially center split. Bony restriction in the hip joint, as the hip joint bone gets jammed into socket because of extreme coxa vara angle (angulation between the neck and shaft of the thigh bone) leading to restrictions in movement. These jams will not happen when you do a side split as there is slight rotation occurring in the joint and allows the action to happen.  Other reason could be ligamentous (pubofemoral ligament) limitation as the ligament tightens and it limits the further movement. This ligament realigns and will relax while doing forward and side split. So, it will not restrict your movement other than center split. You can try tilting your pelvis forward so that there can be some relief with limitation in both the cases. For more information consult a physiotherapist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! It sounds like you may be experiencing some hip impingement when attempting the center split. Hip impingement occurs when the bones of the hip joint rub against each other, causing pain and limited range of motion.

There are a few things you can try to address this issue:

1. Stretch regularly, but gently. Focus on stretching the adductor muscles in your inner thigh and the external rotators of your hip. Avoid forcing yourself into positions that cause pain.

2. Strengthen the muscles around your hip joint. Strengthening exercises, such as clamshells and hip bridges, can help to support the joint and prevent impingement.

3. Adjust your technique when doing the center split. Instead of spreading your legs as wide as possible, try to keep your knees bent and your hips rotated forward. This will help to avoid the impingement and allow for a deeper stretch.

4. Consider consulting a physical therapist. A physical therapist can help you to identify any imbalances or weaknesses in your hip muscles and work with you to develop a personalized plan to address the issue.

It's important to listen to your body and avoid pushing too hard too fast. With patience and persistence, you can work to improve your center split while avoiding injury.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Thanks for writing in. The center split you are referring to is called as the "splitting" of the leg. This is done by rotating the foot inwards while keeping the knee straight. When you do this, your whole body weight gets transferred to the front side of the knee. This is where the pain originates from. When you rotate the knee backwards and hips forward, the pressure is shifted to the other side and hence the pain reduces. It is possible to reduce the pain through stretching exercises. You should start with gentle stretching of the groin muscles and then gradually move onto full splits. However, if the pain persists even after adequate stretching, you may need to consult a physician who will advise you further investigations like X-ray, MRI etc. In case it is a ligament injury, physical therapy along with medicines will help.

But as you said that a condom had been used all the time and you only have a doubt of spill, the chances of a pregnancy is very very low. As the pill was taken within 24 hours of sex, its success is also very high.  This pill is a progesterone hormone in a high dose. So, the period would be slightly delayed. Some do get their periods within 10 days of the pill, but I would suggest you wait until seven to 10 days of the expected date. So, wait until the 25th of this month. She should get her periods by then. If still no periods, it is due to the deranged hormonal levels due to the pill. If still doubtful about condom failure, have a home urine pregnancy test. Once confirmed as negative, have tablet Duoluton-L (Ethinylestradiol and Levonorgestrel) or Intimacy plus 3 (Ethinylestradiol and Desogestrel) or Novelon or Ovral-G - one tablet twice a day for 10 days (throw away the 21st pill). No matter what the cause is (except pregnancy) she will have her periods within seven to 10 days. Hope I have clarified your query, do write back if any more queries. All the best. For more information consult an obstetrician and gynaecologist online  Take care.

input: Hello doctor,I have blood coming in loose stool for the past one year but I do not feel any pain. What is the reason?
answer_icliniq: Hi. Blood in stool is not a normal condition as you are having the problem for one year. It should be investigated in detail and the following work-up will be useful. Rectal, anal area examination, stool routine microscopic examination, proctoscopy examination, colonoscopy, if needed. If needed during colonoscopy, biopsy taken from the abnormal area if found for histopathology examination. This work-up will be helpful to rule out causes for blood in stool like a polyp, proctitis, piles, colitis, diverticulitis, any growth, if present, etc. If the color of blood in stool is of brown-red color than bleeding is from the upper gastrointestinal tract. If colour is bright red then the cause for bleeding is from the lower gastrointestinal tract. So, from your provided history, this work-up should be done and above causes should be ruled out. One diagnosis cannot be given. Consult general surgeon or gastroenterologist for examination and above work up and according to cause identified further treatment plan can be decided.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Blood in stool can be a concerning symptom and it's important to have it evaluated by a healthcare provider. There are many different causes of blood in stool, ranging from minor to serious conditions. Some possible causes of blood in stool include:

1. Hemorrhoids - These are swollen and inflamed veins in the anus and lower rectum that may bleed during bowel movements.

2. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) - Conditions such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis can cause inflammation in the bowel, which may lead to bloody diarrhea.

3. Diverticulitis - This is a condition in which small pouches form in the colon and become infected or inflamed, causing abdominal pain and bloody stool.

4. Anal fissures - These are small tears in the lining of the anus that can cause pain and bleeding during bowel movements.

5. Colorectal cancer - This is a serious condition in which cancer cells grow in the colon or rectum, and may cause blood in stool as well as other symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss.

It's important to have a healthcare provider evaluate your symptoms to determine the cause of your blood in stool. They may recommend tests such as a colonoscopy, stool analysis, or imaging studies to help make a diagnosis. Treatment will depend on the underlying cause of the blood in stool, and may include medication or surgery in certain cases.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, welcome to Chat Doctor forum. I am sorry to hear that you have blood in your stools for the past one year. You should immediately consult a physician who can examine you and get some tests done to find out what the cause of this problem is. It could be due to hemorrhoids or other causes like colitis or diverticulosis etc. So don't worry and consult a physician as soon as possible. Hope this helps. Take care.

input: Hello doctor,Four months ago, I consulted you on this platform for premature complexes which I was having without any other symptoms. Below is my query and your answer - I am a male of 48 years of age. I have a lean build and do regular exercise. Since childhood, I had a tendency for heart palpitations and premature beats. After a few tests, anxiety was found to be the main cause.  You had said that most probably these premature complexes are originating from ventricles which are leading to the symptoms. These are usually benign and not life threatening. The only concern remains is that of coronary artery disease, which is also less likely as these are occurring from a long time and you are not having any other symptoms. Lack of sleep, stress, alcohol, smoking, caffeinated beverages are known triggering factors for these due to sympathetic overactivity. You should also get thyroid test done. I think, just be on a safer side, you should get one treadmill test done to rule out coronary artery disease and echo should be repeated. Afterwards, I met a cardiologist and got an ECG and echo tests done. The tests were normal. The cardiologist said that there is no need for TMT test since I do running and other exercises daily and there is no known risk factor for CAD. But the VPCs continued for a month.Then, I realized that I was taking a weight gainer supplement from the last one year which contained creatinine. Two months back, I was not doing any exercise due to a small fracture in my elbow but continued to take this supplement. The doctor advised me to stop the supplement immediately since this could be the cause of missed beats. Then I read in the internet and found out that there have been cases of irregular heart beats due to creatinine supplementation. I stopped taking the supplement although it was from a reputed firm and did not contain any steroids. The missed beats reduced after stopping the supplement and from the last two months, it has come to a normal level of one or two in a day. But somehow my mind started getting preoccupied with the thoughts of heart disease and I started reading about it from the internet and even textbooks.I have been thin and slim since my childhood, have been quite active physically, no family history of heart disease, no diabetes, no hypertension, non-smoker, rarely eat fried foods. My lipid profile is normal with HDL being about 55 whenever tested, CRP is around 0.5. But in spite of this, I was not able to free my mind from worries of CAD. A month back, I did quite a lot of pushups after a gap of four to five months. After three to four days, I started having pain in my chest here and there mostly at rest. After a week I got an ECG done which was normal. The pain subsided slowly but whenever I did some exercise which put a strain on the chest muscle I started having pain and with pain, more worries.Then I met a psychiatrist. He said that I have got into an obsessive loop, which is part of health anxiety disorder which is causing these psychosomatic symptoms of chest pain. He advised me to take some antidepressants for three months, do Yoga and meditation and take some sessions of cognitive behavior therapy. I am reluctant to take antidepressants but have already started doing some meditation and Yoga. He also prescribed Alprazolam .25 mg on SOS basis. Now the pain is subsiding slowly and obsessive thoughts are also reducing. I have stopped doing any exercise that would put a strain on the chest. I do not know how long it will take to resume it. In a recent blood test, two months back my vitamin D3 was at 28. Could it be the cause of the chest pain? Secondly, I stopped the supplement but continued some strenuous exercises without taking a proper diet. Could it be the cause of it? Please guide me. How to get rid of this unwanted health anxiety which I have got into?

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be especially helpful in identifying and addressing unhelpful thoughts and behaviors related to health anxiety. Understanding and addressing the underlying causes of your anxiety can help reduce physical symptoms as well.

I just wanted to know what kind of operation is done for this cystic structure and after removal will I be able to get pregnant and the doctors told me that my baby bag is twisted (facing the other side) and the chance of getting pregnant is 15 % lower than the normal ladies. Is it correct? And how it can be corrected?
answer_icliniq: Hello. As the CA 125 (coelomic epithelial antigen) levels are normal, the cyst is likely to be a simple ovarian cyst. A cyst of size more than 4 cm if symptomatic can be removed with laparoscopy. But if asymptomatic then a trial of low dose oc (oral contraceptive) pills can be given for two cycles to allow natural resolution of the cyst. Secondly, retroverted uterus as in your case has reduced chances of conception, but with the change of position during intercourse that can be overcome. For infertility management, it is important to learn your hormonal status and regularity of your menstrual cycle. Please follow up with details. Regards. For more information consult an obstetrician and gynaecologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

The type of operation done for an ovarian cyst depends on several factors such as the size and type of cyst, your medical history, and your future pregnancy plans. Your doctor will evaluate your condition and suggest the most appropriate treatment option.

In some cases, a cyst may resolve on its own and may not require any treatment. If the cyst is large or causing symptoms, surgery may be necessary to remove it.

After surgery, your ability to get pregnant depends on various factors such as the type of cyst, the extent of the surgery, and any other underlying fertility issues. In general, most women are able to conceive after the removal of an ovarian cyst.

Regarding your "baby bag" being twisted or retroverted uterus, research has shown that it does not affect fertility negatively. Retroverted uterus occurs in about 20-25% of women and is considered normal. It does not need any treatment unless it is causing symptoms.

Therefore, I suggest you talk to your doctor for further evaluation and clarification on your condition and treatment options.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Thanks for writing to us. The ovarian cysts can be removed either by laparoscopy or open surgery depending upon the size and nature of the cyst. Certain types of cysts like dermoid cyst may need to be removed only if they cause symptoms or become infected. In your case, the cyst is not causing any problems and seems to be benign in nature and hence does not require any treatment at present. But as you mentioned that the fallopian tube is twisted, so it is important to consult an infertility specialist and get evaluated before planning conception.

Hello! Based on your description, it's possible that you have a condition called intertrigo. Intertrigo is a skin condition that occurs in areas where skin folds or rubs together, such as the armpits, under the breasts, or in the groin area. Symptoms include itching, redness, and oozing or crusting.

Excessive sweating can contribute to the development of intertrigo, as moisture can promote the growth of bacteria and fungi that can cause infection. It's important to keep the affected areas as clean and dry as possible to prevent further irritation.

You may consider using an antifungal or antibacterial cream to help treat the infection. In more severe cases, a prescription topical or oral medication may be necessary.

It's also important to address any factors that may be contributing to excessive sweating, such as obesity or certain medications. Additionally, wearing loose-fitting, breathable clothing and avoiding tight clothing can help prevent intertrigo from recurring.

I would recommend seeing a dermatologist or your primary care physician for an evaluation and proper diagnosis, as there can be other conditions that may present similar symptoms.

Hello! I'm sorry to hear about your acne. Acne can be a frustrating condition to deal with, but there are treatments available that can help you manage it. Here's what I recommend:

1. Practice good skincare. Use a gentle, non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) cleanser and moisturizer daily. Avoid scrubbing your face too harshly or using hot water, as this can irritate your skin and make your acne worse.

2. Use topical treatments. Over-the-counter products containing benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid or topical retinoids can help to unclog pores and decrease inflammation. Apply them as directed on the packaging.

3. Consider prescription medication. If your acne is severe, your doctor may prescribe topical or oral medications to help clear it up. These can include antibiotic creams or pills, oral contraceptives (for women) or isotretinoin (a powerful oral acne medication).

4. Consult a dermatologist. If your acne is persistent and doesn't improve with topical treatments, schedule an appointment with a dermatologist. They can evaluate your skin and recommend a personalized treatment plan.

In terms of removing the marks left by acne, there are a few options available, such as topical products containing alpha-hydroxy acids or hydroquinone, microneedling, or certain laser treatments. However, these treatments should only be done under the guidance of a dermatologist.

input: Hello doctor,I and my fiancee had intercourse a month back with a condom and also she had an emergency contraceptive pill. I bought it from a medical. They asked her to take it before one hour of intercourse. She had a regular period. Her last period was on 7th of last month but it is 11th of next month now and till now she did not get her periods. She does not want to get pregnant now as she has her exams in a few months. She is doing heavy exercise like cycling, spot jogging, sit ups. And also she has taken two raw papayas, four pineapples and three times ginger syrup. I am sure that condom did not get broken. My doubts are will she get pregnant? Is there really a pill available to be taken before intercourse. Is that pill true? What she can do further to get her periods? Can she take Probers tablet for getting it?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Stress plays important role in periods. She might be freaking out with the fear of getting pregnant, with exams on the head causing a delay in her periods. Please consider doing a pregnancy test, most likely, it will be negative, and that will help her relax. Periods will gradually occur. No need to worry. Yes, there are medicines for getting periods, but they might worsen her condition by causing mood swings, as she already has taken an emergency contraceptive. Secondly, emergency contraceptives should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, the earlier, the better effect. She has taken it quite early even before intercourse, so chances of pregnancy are nil.
answer_chatgpt:
There is always a chance of pregnancy with any form of contraception, including condoms and emergency contraceptives. However, the likelihood of pregnancy is reduced when both methods are used together.

The emergency contraceptive pill is a real medication that can be effective if taken within 72 hours (or up to 120 hours for some brands) of unprotected intercourse. It works by delaying or preventing ovulation, or preventing fertilization of the egg. It is not a pill that can be taken before intercourse.

Heavy exercise and certain foods can potentially affect menstrual cycles, but it is not guaranteed. It is important for your fiancee to speak with a healthcare provider about any concerns regarding her menstrual cycle, as they can conduct tests and provide guidance on the best course of action.

It is not recommended to take Probers (Progesterone) tablets to induce menstruation without consulting a healthcare provider first. They can provide a safe and effective method to induce menstruation if necessary.

It is important to discuss all contraception options and use them properly and consistently to reduce the risk of pregnancy. Condoms are effective at preventing sexually transmitted infections, but may not always prevent pregnancy. Emergency contraceptive pills are a backup option, but should not be relied upon as primary contraception.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Pregnancy is unlikely to occur if you have used the condom correctly, unless there was some breakage or slippage during sex.2) Emergency contraception (EC) is not a pill. It is a combination of hormones which is given as a single dose after unprotected sex. EC is most effective within 72 hours of unprotected sex.3) There is no such thing as "pregnancy prevention" pill.4) Your girlfriend needs to wait and observe for her menstrual cycle to come back. If it does not come by end of this month, she should get a urine pregnancy test done.5) You can help your girlfriend by giving her plenty of fluids and nutritious foods.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 26-year-old male. I had protected sex with a sex worker a month back. I used one condom, she gave oral sex and post that had vaginal sex for 5 minutes. Once I finished off, I went to the bathroom and got cleaned off. I could not see any tear as such on the condom. I just washed my penis and got back home. The same night after 2 hours I pulled my foreskin behind to clean my penis with soap. The frenulum got too tight and tore. It started bleeding. I washed my penis and let it heal for 2 weeks.What are the chances of getting HIV from what had happened? I do not have any symptoms. Just had fever for a day and now I have a common cold. On the 15th-day post exposure (yesterday), I went for the HIV PCR RNA yesterday. The results are yet to come. Will the torn frenulum give chance for HIV virus to get in after 2 hours? I am feeling very anxious and stressed out. I really need your guidance. Please suggest what I need to do to rule out HIV and live a normal life. Please help.
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. The chances of transmission of HIV with given description is almost nil. The HIV test is likely to be negative. If the test is negative, it is almost conclusive provided there is no further risk exposure. The chance of test result coming positive later is almost nil. You can go for HIV antibodies tests after 3 months exposure to have final conclusive results to relieve your anxiety. For more information consult a community medicine physician online
answer_chatgpt:
As your sexual encounter was protected and there was no noticeable tear in the condom, your risk for HIV transmission during sex is relatively low. However, it is still important to get tested because condoms can break or slip off during intercourse. The torn frenulum doesn't increase the chances of HIV transmission on its own. 

The PCR RNA test is a reliable method of detecting HIV infection early on. However, it may not be accurate during the window period (the time when the body is producing antibodies to HIV but the virus is not yet detectable by a test), which is about 2-4 weeks after exposure. A follow-up test is recommended after 4-6 weeks to confirm the results. 

In addition to HIV, it's also recommended to get tested for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis. It's important to use protection during each sexual encounter to prevent STIs and unwanted pregnancies. 

Lastly, it's important to take care of your mental health during this time of anxiety and stress. Seeking support from a mental health professional or a support group can be helpful.

I have no other symptoms but more blood has come out, no mucous or clots either. I feel well. Could it be coincidental that my period has come back or could I have injured myself? What are the signs of injury and at what point should I get checked out?By the way of background, I have been waiting for my period since last year. I stopped taking the pill thinking my period would come but it never did. I had irregular periods prior to taking the pill (hence why I got on the pill). My periods were always relatively heavy. I also have had a number of ovarian cysts over the last two to three years which have caused me pain previously. I am not polycystic and have not undergone any treatment but for the removal of ovarian cysts three years back due to torsion.
answer_icliniq: Hello. As your history suggests that you experienced bleeding post insertion and usage of sex toy (dildo). There are two ways it can cause injury in women - one by frictional lesions experienced as stretching and vaginal wall tears leading to bleeding (reddish spotting to heavy) or presence of cervicitis or cervical erosions which can bleed after the act of insertion or intercourse (often darkish brown discharge to reddish spotting). This calls for a per speculum examination to rule out either -vaginal mucosal injury or cervicitis. Now that you have been amenorrhoeic (absence of mensuration) since last four months, there is all likelihood that post sexual act, due to orgasm and increased endorphins, your menses may have been initiated and have increased inflow in next few days without any discomfort. The chances of bleeding being menses and heavy is high considering there is no pain or fever and that you did not have your menses for the last four months. You should get an ultrasound pelvis done to check for endometrial blood collection which shall confirm menses and also a per speculum exam which shall rule out any cervicitis or vaginal mucous lesions. I hope I have answered your query in detail, Avoid use of sex toy till cause is ascertained and bleeding stops. Please consult your gynecologist.

In the meantime, you can monitor your symptoms and keep track of the amount of bleeding. If the bleeding continues or becomes heavier, it would be a good idea to see a healthcare provider for further evaluation. They may perform a pelvic exam or ultrasound to determine the cause of the bleeding and determine if any treatment is needed. 

Given your history of irregular periods and ovarian cysts, it may also be a good idea to discuss your menstrual cycle with your healthcare provider to determine if any further evaluation or treatment is needed. 

I hope this information helps, and please dont hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns!

input: Hi doctor, My last exposure was protected but I am not sure about whether the vaginal fluid touched or not since I was drunk that time. After that, I went to an HIV specialist and he suggested me HIV DNA PCR test at 66 days period. The result is HIV 1 not detected.Then at 83 days, tridot rapid test is negative. 88-day tridot rapid test negative. 93-day tridot non-reactive. 99-day tridot (immuno filtration) antibodies 1 and 2 nonreactive. Then I took HbsAg, HCV, VRD total all are non-reactive.Is it enough for HIV testing? Is DNA PCR at 66 days (in window ) period useful? Is tridot test useful or not?In the window period time, I used fever tablets, antibiotics, and Levocetirizine many days. Will it affect my window period? Please give me brief information. I have a family and a child. Can I have sex with my wife without protection? Next test needed or not?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome\x80\x8b to ChatDoctor. It is great that you have been found negative for HIV and other STIs (sexually transmitted infection). All the tests which you had taken for HIV were highly sensitive and specific and gives accurate results. It is unlikely for antibiotics and other medications which you had taken for fever could affect the result. Window period is the time taken for antibodies to develop after infection and then get detected by a particular test. The length of the window period varies between individuals. There are recommendations and I also suggest my patients to repeat the test at six months of last exposure. Testing at three and six months of possible exposure can detect almost all HIV infections. You can take precautions (consistently and correctively using a condom) with your wife until the time you are undergoing tests. I hope this helps.  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Based on the information provided, it appears that your risk of HIV transmission was low because you used protection during sexual activity. However, it is possible that the vaginal fluid could have touched the skin around the condom, which may increase the risk of transmission compared to a completely protected encounter.

Regarding your HIV testing, the DNA PCR test at 66 days after the exposure is indeed useful since it is able to detect HIV earlier than antibody tests. The HIV RNA/DNA PCR test is generally considered conclusive after 21 days, but when used in combination with subsequent antibody tests, it can provide additional reassurance.

The tridot test is an antibody test that detects the presence of antibodies to HIV, which the body develops in response to the infection. The test is reliable after the window period, which is the interval between the time of infection and the time when the antibodies are detectable. The window period for most antibody tests is about 4 weeks to 3 months, depending on the specific test used.

It is important to note that, during the window period, HIV tests may not detect the virus, which means a negative test result does not necessarily rule out infection. However, since you have tested negative at multiple time points outside the window period, it is unlikely that you have HIV.

The use of fever tablets, antibiotics, or Levocetirizine during the window period should not affect the accuracy of the HIV tests.

Regarding your question about having sex with your wife, it's important to note that while your test results suggest that you are not infected with HIV, there is still a potential risk of other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). It is recommended that you use protection during sexual activity with your wife and consider getting tested for other STIs as well. It is always a good idea to discuss sexual health with your partner and use protection to prevent STIs and unwanted pregnancies. A follow-up test may be recommended by your healthcare provider depending on your individual risk factors.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Thanks for writing in. I understand your concern. The tests that you have done are appropriate for your situation. DNA PCR test is done when there is a possibility of exposure by genital secretions. It can detect HIV for up to 66 days after exposure. Tridot test is done to detect HIV antigen in blood. It may be positive even if viral load is very low. You should do this test only once as it has high false positive results. The immunofiltration test is done to detect antibody against HIV. It requires fresh serum sample. If it is negative then you need not worry about HIV. You can have unprotected sex with your wife provided she is not infected. However, if she is infected then she needs to take precautions and get tested.

I'm sorry to hear that you are suffering from penile/balanitis infection for the last three months. The symptoms you described could be due to a bacterial, fungal or viral infection. Treatment for this condition usually involves medication to eliminate the infection, as well as measures to prevent recurrence. Here are some suggestions:

1. Antifungal or Antibacterial Medication: Depending on the cause of your infection, your doctor may prescribe antifungal or antibiotic medication. The medication may come in the form of orally ingested tablets, creams, or ointments.

2. Good Hygiene: In addition to medication, it is crucial to maintain good hygiene habits. This can include gently and effectively cleansing the area, rinsing thoroughly and patting dry, particularly after sexual activities.

3. Limiting or Avoiding Certain Habits: To speed the process of healing, it may be necessary to limit or avoid habits such as sexual activities until the infection is completely resolved if possible.

4. Avoiding Harsh Soaps and Talcum Powder: It would be helpful to avoid using harsh soaps or talcum powder in the area as they may irritate and contribute to the infection.

5. Don't Scratch: Patients are usually sensitive and might scratch at the area; however, it is crucial to avoid any excessive scratching or rubbing that could worsen the inflammation.

If these measures do not provide significant relief, it may be necessary to consult with an urologist or infectious disease specialist. They may prescribe additional diagnostic and therapeutic procedures.

input: Hello doctor,I need a psychiatric opinion for my good friend who has been treated for catatonic schizophrenia.She is a 27 year old European woman.She had in total three episodes of catatonia that required hospitalization.But I suspect it may have been depression instead, since she volunteered hospitalization.She has been given Solian (amisulpride) from 2011 to 2013 and then in 2014.Then she had problems of too high prolactin and they changed it to Abilify (aripiprazole).She also gained a lot of fat (about 40kg in 5 years) and seems to keep getting slowly bigger, since she is often hungry, probably as a side effect of the medicines.She is not taking other medications and she is otherwise healthy.She declared that she is not afraid any more, after switching from Solian to Abilify, but she feels unhappy.She appears much less talkative and lively than she used to be years ago. She is less confident too.I suspect that she may have depression rather than schizophrenia and I noticed that she has significant anxiety, victim mentality (quite important) and some sleeping problems.She is insecure and she dropped out of several educations in the last couple of years.She has abusive parents and she went back living with them.She has recently received cognitive therapy but she felt insulted and not helped.She and I wish to find a solution for her.Thank you.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. I can understand your concern. I have read the query and after reading the history of hers I can tell you that these symptoms suggest more towards some neurotic illness specifically depression rather than catatonic schizophrenia. In catatonic schizophrenia patients show symptoms like negativism, echolalia (automatic repetition of words spoken by other persons), echopraxia (involuntary or automatic repetition of the movements of other persons), waxy flexibility etc. She has developed illness in episodes and not continuously, which also points more towards depression because psychotic illnesses run a continuous course. Her symptoms like lack of confidence, anxiety, poor sleep, feelings of insecurity, feeling of unhappiness, less talkative etc., suggest depression. There is no history of any suspiciousness, no history suggestive of hallucinations which weakens diagnosis of a psychotic disorder. So, in my opinion from available history her diagnosis is more likely to be depression rather than catatonic schizophrenia. Even in severe depression individuals may present with depressive stupor which can mimic a catatonia. Please visit her doctor again and ask for reevaluation of diagnosis. She responded to amisulpride ( ChatDoctor.  Aripiprazole can help in psychosis but in depression its use is limited. In my opinion there is need to add some good antidepressant.
answer_chatgpt:
It is important to keep in mind that a definitive diagnosis can only be made after a comprehensive evaluation by a qualified mental health professional. However, based on the information provided, it is possible that your friend could be experiencing a combination of depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) due to experiences with her abusive parents. While a diagnosis of schizophrenia cannot be ruled out based on your description of her symptoms, other conditions such as depression and PTSD can also present with similar symptoms such as anxiety, sleeping problems, and feelings of unhappiness.

The side effects that your friend is experiencing are also common with antipsychotic medications, such as Solian and Abilify. Hyperprolactinemia (high prolactin levels) is a common side effect of certain antipsychotics, which can lead to weight gain and other physical symptoms. Although switching to Abilify may have helped to address the high prolactin levels, the medication can still have side effects such as increased hunger and weight gain.

Considering your friend's negative experience with cognitive therapy, it may be worth seeking out alternative forms of therapy such as interpersonal therapy, psychotherapy or mindfulness-based therapy. These therapies may be better suited to address her specific needs and personal preferences. In addition, it may be helpful to encourage her to engage in physical activity or exercise, which has been shown to be effective for mood and anxiety disorders.

Overall, it is important that your friend continues to work closely with her mental health professionals to manage her symptoms and side effects to find the most effective treatment plan for her.

input: Hi doctor,My girlfriend is 35 years old. She is obese, exercises regularly and tries to watch her diet. In spite of these, she is prediabetic. Her fasting blood glucose is typically around 105 mg/dL. Her A1C is normally in the range of 5.7% to 6%. She takes Metformin to manage the prediabetes. Her blood pressure is checked regularly and is always good. Last time, her blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg. Her eGFR has been tested several times and is always above 90.Recently, she had a medical checkup in her office, and the report was obesity and protein in the urine. So, she went to She went to her GP who performed a 24-hour protein in the urine test. 520 mg per 24 hours was the result of this test. She was referred to an endocrinologist and a nephrologist. The nephrologist did perform an ultrasound. Neither the endocrinologist or the nephrologist were terribly concerned. My girlfriend discussed using ACE inhibitors with the nephrologist, but he did not think they were necessary as her blood pressure was normal. He recommended diet, exercise, weight loss and monitoring.The nephrologist did not tell her that she has phase 1 CKD. But, it sounds like she has. Is this correct? Both the endocrinologist and the nephrologist felt that it would not impact her ability to live a healthy life. Is this correct? If she has CKD, how long will it take to progress? What is the long-term prognosis? Is healthy pregnancy possible? Apart from diet, exercise and weight loss, are there other things you would like to recommend?
answer_icliniq: Hi. Welcome to ChatDoctor. We are here to help you. Considering her prediabetes a cause of her proteinuria, yes, she would be categorized in stage 1 CKD (chronic kidney disease). However, that is very unlikely that such a prediabetes at this age is going to cause proteinuria. Yes, this is not going to impact if does not worsen further. It will not progress much as her diabetes is well controlled. The prognosis of her condition is good, and a healthy pregnancy without any complication is possible. I want to mention that she needs a repeat 24 hours protein test done after a month to reach a conclusion as a single time urine protein can occur due to many causes like heavy exercises and fever. I would recommend ACE inhibitors, ANA (anti-nuclear antibody), C3, C4 level test and ultrasound kidneys in case her urine protein persists even after one month.
answer_chatgpt:
Based on the information provided, it appears that your girlfriend is in the early stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a urine protein excretion of 520 mg per 24 hours. The diagnosis of CKD is made when there is evidence of kidney damage (in this case protein in the urine) for more than three months, regardless of the cause. 

It is good that she is under the care of both an endocrinologist and a nephrologist who have recommended lifestyle modifications, including diet, exercise, weight loss, and monitoring. These are important interventions that can slow the progression of CKD and reduce the risk of other complications. ACE inhibitors and other medications may be considered in the future if her kidney function declines, but for now, the focus should be on addressing the underlying causes and maintaining her overall health.

The rate of progression of CKD can vary depending on the underlying cause, the level of kidney function, and other factors. It is important for her to have regular follow-up with her healthcare providers to monitor her kidney function and adjust her treatment plan as needed.

The long-term prognosis for CKD is variable and depends on many factors, including the underlying cause, the degree of kidney damage, and the effectiveness of treatment. With proper management, many people with CKD can maintain stable kidney function for many years and live a healthy life.

Pregnancy can be challenging for women with CKD, and it is recommended that she discuss this with her healthcare provider if she plans to become pregnant. With proper management and close monitoring, healthy pregnancy is possible, but it is important to understand the risks and potential complications.

In addition to diet, exercise, and weight loss, other strategies that may be helpful for people with CKD include managing blood pressure and cholesterol levels, avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol consumption, and managing other health conditions such as diabetes and heart disease.

Overall, it is important for her to work closely with her healthcare team to manage her prediabetes and kidney disease, and to take steps to maintain her overall health and well-being.

Pregnancy is possible if the kidneys function well.3. Diet and exercise are very important for everyone especially for someone with CKD.4. There are many medications available which can help control the disease. Please consult your doctors before taking any medicine. Hope this helps.

input: Hello doctor,I had a routine echo done a couple of weeks ago and just got the results yesterday. The sheet says moderate pulmonary hypertension with peak pressure 54 mmHg and central venous pressure of 15.0. Since I only picked up the results no one explained it to me but set up an appointment with lung and heart specialist in six months. What does all this mean? I am a hypertensive and pre-diabetic. Currently, I am on Lisinopril 10 mg.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. This means pressure in the pulmonary circulation has increased likely due to lung problem (if echo is not showing any abnormalities other than this). Likely this is related to obesity although we need to rule out other causes of pulmonary hypertension by doing CT scan and other few investigations. Do you have shortness of breath, any other symptoms to suggest some cause? You should focus on healthy lifestyle and weight loss.  For more information consult a cardiologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Pulmonary hypertension is a condition where the blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs becomes elevated, which can lead to strain on the right side of the heart. The peak pressure measurement of 54 mmHg indicates that the pressure in these arteries is moderately elevated, and the central venous pressure of 15.0 indicates that there may be some congestion in the blood vessels leading to the heart.

There are many possible causes of pulmonary hypertension, including underlying lung or heart disease, blood clots in the lungs, or connective tissue disorders, among others. It is important to follow up with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or cardiologist, to determine the underlying cause and to begin appropriate treatment.

Your current medications, including lisinopril, may also need to be adjusted or modified to treat pulmonary hypertension. It is important to continue to monitor your blood pressure and blood sugar levels as well, as poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes can contribute to the development and progression of pulmonary hypertension.

Overall, pulmonary hypertension can be a serious condition that requires proper diagnosis and treatment. I would encourage you to keep your follow-up appointment and to discuss any concerns or questions with your healthcare provider.

Also, you should consult your cardiologist regarding these investigations. Hope this answers your question. Regards

Repeated chemical treatments like smoothening and keratin treatment can cause a lot of damage to your hair, especially if they are done too close together. The damage you mention, such as frizz, roughness, and brittleness, may be caused by the cumulative effect of these treatments. However, it is possible to repair the damage done to your hair.

Here are a few things you can do to repair your hair:

1. Trim your hair: Cut off the damaged ends of your hair to prevent further breakage and promote healthy hair growth.

2. Moisturize your hair: Use moisturizing shampoos, conditioners, and hair masks to hydrate your hair and prevent it from becoming dry and brittle. Look for products containing natural oils, like coconut oil or argan oil.

3. Avoid heat styling: Excessive heat styling, such as blow-drying, flat ironing or curling, can worsen the damage to your hair. Try to avoid these activities and air dry your hair as much as possible.

4. Protect your hair: Wear a scarf or hat to protect your hair from UV rays and wind damage. Also, avoid tying your hair too tightly as this can cause further damage.

5. Eat a healthy diet: Eating a balanced diet that includes plenty of fruits, vegetables, and protein can help promote healthy hair growth.

6. Consult a hair expert or dermatologist: If your hair damage is severe or you're not seeing any improvement, you may want to consult a hair expert or dermatologist.

Remember that repairing damaged hair takes time and effort. Be patient and gentle with your hair, and eventually, you'll notice a difference.

answer_icliniq: Hi. Getting periods in between only means that the follicles were not healthy enough. This is usually triggered by poor ovulation induction. Month next to that, have CCQ (Clomiphene citrate) 100 mg from the third day of periods and at the same time start on HMG (Menotropin) or Humog (human menopausal gonadotropin) 75 or 112.5 IU. Further dose depending on follicles response.

3. Medications: Certain medications, such as aspirin or blood thinners, can increase the risk of bleeding.

input: Respected doctor,I would like to know about the remedies or medicines for alcoholism for my husband who drinks a lot almost daily and has a bad habit of eating pan and ghutka. It is not ethical or safe to administer medications to someone without their knowledge or consent. Additionally, there is no single medication that can cure alcoholism, and the effectiveness of any treatment depends on individual factors, such as the severity of addiction, overall health status, and personal motivation to quit.

I would recommend seeking professional help for your husband's addiction, such as visiting a doctor or addiction specialist who can assess his condition and recommend appropriate treatment options. Behavioral therapies, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or motivational interviewing, have proven to be effective in treating alcohol addiction.

Furthermore, you can reach out to support groups such as Al-Anon or Nar-Anon for family members of individuals struggling with addiction for guidance and support. It is important to set boundaries for yourself and your daughter's safety if your husband's behavior becomes abusive.

Remember that recovery from alcoholism is a long-term process, and it requires ongoing support and commitment. Encourage your husband to seek help and offer your support throughout his journey towards sobriety.

Also, if you experience prolonged or heavy bleeding or any other concerning symptoms, you should consult a healthcare provider.

It is also recommended that you use a regular method of birth control to prevent unwanted pregnancies and avoid the need for emergency contraception.

However, if he's experiencing a lot of discomfort and complications, he may want to discuss other treatment options with his doctor, such as immunotherapy or a bladder-sparing procedure.

Bladder removal, or cystectomy, is generally recommended for invasive bladder cancer or high-grade non-invasive cancer that has not responded to other treatments. It's an intensive surgery that involves removing the bladder and creating a new way for urine to exit the body, often using part of the intestines. This decision should be made in consultation with your father's urologist or oncologist based on the type, stage, and location of the cancer, as well as your father's overall health and lifestyle.

It's important to continue monitoring his cancer regularly and to follow any treatment or surveillance plans recommended by his doctors, as bladder cancer can recur even after successful treatment. Encourage your father to speak openly with his healthcare providers about any concerns or questions he may have about his treatment plan, as well as any side effects or complications he experiences.

input: Hello doctor,I have contacted my psychiatrist because of day-time sleepiness and weariness. I am a student, so I have a lot of work to do and sometimes do not sleep at night. He suggested the use of Modafinil. While doing some research, all the side effects did not bother me, except for SJS syndrome. My psychiatrist did not have experience with this side effect while dealing with other patients. I am a bit anxious about it, so I decided to have someone else to give me advice about it. What do you think and is there a way to predict or avoid SJS?
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. You may know that Modafinil is a psychostimulant  ChatDoctor.  It is known to cause cutaneous side effects in some people. SJS (Steven-Johnson syn
answer_chatgpt:
Modafinil is a medication commonly used to treat daytime sleepiness and fatigue in patients with narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, and shift work sleep disorder. Although rare, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a potentially life-threatening adverse reaction to modafinil. SJS is a condition in which the skin and mucous membranes (lining the mouth, nose, and eyes) blister and peel off.

While it is impossible to predict with certainty who might develop SJS while taking modafinil, there are several known risk factors. These include a prior history of SJS, a genetic predisposition (such as the HLA-B*1502 gene), and concomitant use of other medications (such as lamotrigine). It is important to note that the risk of SJS while taking modafinil is rare, estimated to be in the range of 1 in 1000 to 1 in 10,000 patients.

To avoid SJS, it is essential to be vigilant for signs and symptoms of the condition. These may include fever, malaise, headache, sore throat, cough, and burning or itchy eyes. If any of these symptoms develop, patients should contact their physician immediately to determine if they may be experiencing SJS.

In conclusion, Modafinil can be an effective medication for treating daytime sleepiness and fatigue, but it is essential to understand the potential risks and side effects associated with its use. While SJS is rare, it is important to monitor for symptoms and seek medical attention immediately if they develop.

input: Hello doctor,What is meant by 6/6 right eye, 6/6 left eye and 6/5 uniocular vision with glasses?
answer_icliniq: Hi. In laymen terms, 6 by 6 means scientificly defined perfect vision. In medical terms, 6 by 6 means what you see from six meters, a person with normal vision also sees it from 6 metres. 6 by 5 means what a normal person sees from 5 metres you see it from 6 metres only means better than normal vision. In this case, 6 by 5 is possible with spectacles.
answer_chatgpt:
"6/6" is a measure of visual acuity, also known as "20/20" in the United States. It means that a person can see objects at a distance of 6 meters (20 feet) that a person with normal vision can also see at the same distance. 

"Right eye 6/6, left eye 6/6" means that each eye individually has normal visual acuity without the need for correction with glasses. 

"Unocular vision with glasses 6/5" means that when the person wears glasses, they can see objects at a distance of 6 meters that a person with normal vision can see at 5 meters (16.5 feet). This means their vision with glasses is better than average.
answer_chatdoctor: 6/6 means perfect 20/20 vision. 6/6 both eyes together or 6/6 right eye and 6/6 left eye mean that there is no problem in either eye when tested separately. 6/5 uniocular vision with glasses means that one eye (right or left) has better than 20/20 vision while other eye needs glasses to see clearly. This means that if you wear glasses for reading, your distance vision will be blurred without them.

input: Hello doctor,I need to know all of the differences between depersonalization disorder and just having depression. Please give me all of the differences and how to tell if you have depression or depersonalization. I believe I am experiencing depression. But I just want to make sure it is not depersonalization disorder.
answer_icliniq: Hello. Depersonalization is simply a symptom in which individual has feelings of detached from self. The individuals feel that they have changes and world has become vague and changed. Recently depersonalization has been included in dissociative disorders. This can occur in severe anxiety and even under severe stress too.  Depression is a mood disorder. In depression, symptoms like low mood, reduced energy, tiredness, lack of interest in anything, bad thoughts, reduced psychomotor activity, poor desire, etc., symptoms are seen commonly. Diagnosis is not very difficult and it is easy to make difference between depression and depersonalization. In depersonalization, individual will have simple symptoms like a feeling of detachment from self and no other symptoms are seen usually. Depression patient will show a variety of symptoms. Take care. For more information consult a psychiatrist online  Take care.
answer_chatgpt:
Depression and Depersonalization Disorder are two distinct mental health conditions with different symptoms and diagnostic criteria. Here are some of the key differences:

1. Symptoms:

Depression: Individuals with depression experience persistent sadness, hopelessness, loss of interest, fatigue, changes in appetite, difficulty sleeping or sleeping too much, feelings of guilt and worthlessness, and sometimes suicidal thoughts.

Depersonalization Disorder: Individuals with depersonalization disorder experience a persistent and distressing feeling of being detached or disconnected from their thoughts, feelings, and body. This can include feeling like an outside observer of one's thoughts or body, feeling robotic or robotic-like, or feeling like one is in a dream-like state.

2. Duration:

Depression: Depression is typically a long-term condition that lasts for weeks, months or even years.

Depersonalization Disorder: Depersonalization disorder can be chronic or episodic, with symptoms lasting for months or even years.

3. Triggers:

Depression: Depression can be triggered by stressful life events, trauma, genetics, and other factors.

Depersonalization Disorder: Depersonalization disorder can also be triggered by stress or trauma, but the cause is not fully understood.

4. Treatment:

Depression: Treatment for depression typically involves a combination of medication, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

Depersonalization Disorder: Treatment for depersonalization disorder usually involves psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy, in addition to medication if needed.

To determine if you have depression or depersonalization disorder, it is important to seek the help of a mental health professional. They can diagnose your mental health condition and recommend appropriate treatment based on your symptoms and needs.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Thank you for posting your query. Depression and depersonalization disorder both cause symptoms like sadness, loss of interest in activities, difficulty sleeping or oversleeping, low energy, poor concentration, suicidal ideation etc. The difference is that in depersonalization disorder there is also feeling of being detached from reality and losing touch with reality. In addition, patients suffering from this disorder also experience disturbances in perception such as seeing things differently than others do, hearing voices which are not really there, having illusions, lack of insight, and so on. Hope the information provided would be helpful. All the best.

Yes, there are confirmatory tests available to diagnose breast cancer. After a diagnosis of breast cancer is made, a staging workup is done to determine the extent of the disease. This may include imaging tests such as a CT (computed tomography) or PET (positron emission tomography) scan to look for metastasis to other organs.

Once the cancer has been staged, further tests may be done to determine the specific type of breast cancer and to identify whether certain genes or proteins are present. These tests can help guide treatment decisions and provide important prognostic information.

In some cases, a second opinion from a different specialist may also be helpful in confirming the diagnosis and determining the most appropriate treatment plan for your mother. It is important to discuss all of these options with your mother's healthcare team, and to ask any questions you may have.
