Hello! I'm sorry to hear that your sister has chickenpox. You should definitely take measures to prevent getting the virus. Chickenpox is highly contagious and can easily be spread through contact with saliva, mucus, or blisters of an infected person. The virus can also be spread by airborne respiratory droplets from an infected person's coughing or sneezing.

To prevent getting chickenpox, you should:

1. Avoid close contact with your sister, especially when she is coughing or sneezing. Stay at least 6 feet away from her at all times, and use a mask and gloves when necessary.
2. Wash your hands frequently with soap and water, especially after coming into contact with your sister's belongings or surfaces she may have touched.
3. Get vaccinated if you haven't already had chickenpox. This will greatly reduce your risk of becoming infected or developing a severe case of the disease.
4. Boost your immune system by eating a healthy diet and getting adequate rest and exercise.

The chances of contracting chickenpox when living with an infected person are quite high without vaccination. If you do get infected with chickenpox, it typically takes about 10-21 days for the rash to scab over. It is important to note that you are contagious from one to two days before the rash appears until all the blisters have crusted over, which usually takes around five to ten days. The scabs generally take around one to three weeks to fall off completely.

It is understandable that you are feeling self-conscious about the scabs from the rash. You should take extra care during this time to avoid scratching the blisters, as this can lead to scarring. It is essential to keep the area clean and dry to ensure the blisters heal without infection.

I hope this helps! Stay safe and healthy.

Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your baby's diagnosis. To answer your question, the size of a VSD does play a role in determining the severity of the condition. The larger the VSD, the more blood flows from the left side of the heart to the right side, causing increased pressure and volume, which can lead to poor weight gain and other symptoms.

In your baby's case, if the perimembranous VSD is large and shunting bidirectionally, it is likely causing significant hemodynamic effects, which is why your cardiologist is recommending surgery.

Furosemide is a medication that can help with fluid retention and prevent symptoms such as shortness of breath or swelling. However, it will not cure the VSD and surgery will likely be necessary.

It's important to continue working closely with your pediatric cardiologist and following their recommendations. Surgery for VSD is a common and safe procedure and can greatly improve your baby's quality of life.

input: Hi doctor,What is the difference between IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. IntraLasik is a method in which the corneal flap is taken by laser. In regular Lasik, the corneal flap is taken by a mechanical device which has a metal blade. The rest of the procedures are the same. Contoura vision is a personalized Lasik in which the laser correction is done according to the size and specifications of the individual\s eye. It is something like getting a shirt specially stitched to the individual\s size, whereas regular Lasik is like buying a ready-made shirt.
answer_chatgpt:
IntraLASIK and Contoura LASIK are both advanced technologies used in laser eye surgery to correct refractive errors such as myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. However, they are slightly different from each other.

IntraLASIK, also known as Bladeless LASIK, is a femtosecond laser-assisted LASIK surgery. It involves creating a corneal flap using a femtosecond laser instead of a microkeratome blade, as in traditional LASIK. This technology is known for its precision and reduces the risk of complications during the procedure.

Contoura LASIK, on the other hand, is a type of custom LASIK procedure that uses topography-guided laser technology. It creates a detailed map of the cornea, including all of its subtle irregularities, and uses this information to make highly precise laser treatment patterns. This technology can provide better outcomes for patients with highly irregular corneas, such as those with keratoconus.

In summary, IntraLASIK is a variation of LASIK that uses a laser to create the corneal flap, while Contoura LASIK is a custom LASIK procedure that uses topography-guided laser technology. Your ophthalmologist will recommend which procedure is the most appropriate for your particular situation.
answer_chatdoctor: Both IntraLASIK and Contour LASIK are forms of laser-assisted refractive surgery that use an excimer laser to correct nearsightedness, farsightedness, or astigmatism by reshaping the cornea. The main differences between these two procedures include the type of laser used, the amount of tissue removed, the accuracy of the procedure, the depth of correction possible, and the cost. IntraLASIK uses a femtosecond laser instead of a microkeratome to create a flap in the cornea. This laser is more precise than the microkeratome and can be programmed for individualized treatment plans. It also allows for greater depth of correction and is considered safer because it eliminates the possibility of an accidental cut caused by the microkeratome. Contour LASIK uses a different type of excimer laser. Its advantage over In

Hello there! 

Yes, flavored hookah (also known as shisha) can be injurious to your health. Although some people believe that smoking hookah is less harmful than smoking cigarettes, the truth is that it contains many of the same harmful chemicals and has been linked to a variety of health problems. 

Some potential risks associated with smoking flavored hookah include:

- Lung damage: The smoke from hookah contains high levels of tar, carbon monoxide, and other harmful chemicals, which can cause problems like lung cancer, bronchitis, and emphysema over time.
- Heart problems: Smoking hookah can also increase your risk of heart disease and stroke, as well as problems like high blood pressure and heart attacks.
- Infection risk: Sharing a hookah mouthpiece can increase your risk of infections like herpes and tuberculosis.
- Addiction: Hookah contains nicotine, which can be highly addictive and make it hard to quit.

So, it is advisable to avoid smoking hookah or any form of tobacco. If you're struggling to quit, speak to your doctor or a healthcare professional for advice and support.

Regarding your myocardial bridge, it is a relatively common condition in which one or more of the coronary arteries tunnel under the heart muscle, creating a "bridge-like" structure. The bridge can cause a narrowing of the artery, leading to symptoms such as chest pain or discomfort, shortness of breath, and palpitations.

Although the myocardial bridge is not necessarily a dangerous condition, it can be, in some cases, an associated risk factor for developing heart disease, especially if other factors, like smoking, obesity, or high blood pressure, are present.

Since you have a family history of hypertension, diabetes, and heart disease, I would strongly advise you to adhere to a heart-healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and stress-management techniques, to keep your cardiovascular system in good shape.

The presence of chest pain could be due to chronic stable angina, which is a type of heart disease caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.

Since your family doctor has suggested angiography, it means that they suspect a possible blockage in the coronary arteries. Angiography is an invasive test that involves injecting a contrast dye into the arteries and taking X-rays to visualize the blood vessels. It can help determine the location and extent of any blockages.

However, before proceeding with angiography, your mother's kidney function needs to be thoroughly assessed. With a creatinine level of 1.3, she is already at the lower limit of normal kidney function, and contrast dye can further impair it. Your mother may need to undergo a kidney function test (such as GFR) and possibly a nephrology consultation prior to angiography to ensure her renal function is stable.

In the meantime, it's important to manage your mother's risk factors aggressively. Her blood pressure is still not optimally controlled, as the goal for patients with hypertension is <130/80 mmHg. Her fasting and postprandial blood sugar levels are also above the recommended targets (<100 mg/dL and <140 mg/dL, respectively). She may need to adjust her medication regimen, change her diet, and increase physical activity to better manage these conditions.

Aside from medical management, lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, reducing alcohol intake, and regular exercise can also improve her cardiovascular health. Please discuss all these options with your family doctor and consider seeking a second opinion from a cardiologist to determine the best course of action.

2. Your metabolism may have slowed down: The body adapts to changes in calorie intake and exercise, including lowering your metabolism if it feels like you are not getting enough food. This can make it harder to lose weight and may require more drastic changes to your diet and exercise.

3. Your workout routine might not be effective enough: Although elliptical and treadmill are great cardiovascular exercises, it might not be enough to stimulate weight loss. You may want to incorporate strength training into your workout routine to help increase muscle mass, which can help boost your metabolism and burn more calories.

4. You may have an underlying medical condition: Certain medical conditions, such as hypothyroidism, can make weight loss more difficult. I would recommend checking with your doctor to rule out any medical conditions that could be affecting your weight loss progress.

It is also important to keep in mind that weight loss can be a slow and gradual process, and its not always linear. Sometimes it takes time for the body to adjust to changes, so be patient and consistent with your efforts.

I hope this information helps, and I wish you the best of luck on your weight loss journey.

1. Develop a bedtime routine: Create a bedtime routine that helps you wind down and relax before going to bed. This could include taking a warm bath/shower, reading a book, or practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation.

2. Reduce screen time: Avoid using your phone or other electronic devices before bed. The blue light emitted from screens can disrupt your circadian rhythm and make it harder to fall asleep.

input: Hello doctor,I am a male and I am 30-years-old male. I have a mitral valve problem, and it is moderate mitral stenosis. What remedy do you advise? answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Mitral stenosis is a condition in which the mitral valve in the heart becomes narrow, limiting the flow of blood from the left atrium to the left ventricle. Treatment options for moderate mitral stenosis depend on the severity of the condition and the symptoms that you are experiencing.

Valvuloplasty is a minimally invasive procedure that is used to widen a narrowed valve in the heart. It can be performed using a balloon catheter. The procedure can improve the symptoms of mitral stenosis, but it may not completely cure the condition. Sometimes valvuloplasty needs to be repeated for further treatment.

Valvuloplasty can lead to a few complications such as bleeding, infection, and embolism. However, the risk of complications is relatively low for minimally invasive procedures like valvuloplasty.

As for your medication, Spiromide and tinormin are usually prescribed to lower blood pressure and reduce the symptoms of mitral stenosis. Your doctor may also prescribe other medications to help manage your symptoms.

It is important to speak with your doctor about your concerns and any questions you may have. Your doctor will be able to provide you with more information on the risks and benefits of valvuloplasty and help you decide whether or not it is the right treatment option for you.

input: Hello doctor,My daughter has been experiencing severe back pain, arm stiffness with grip loss, shooting pains down legs when the heel is put to floor and vision blurring when sitting in the car for long periods, for over two years following spinal anesthesia for C-section. MRI scans show nothing and she is taking a maximum dosage of Endone. She now has vascular issues with bilateral inflammation and swelling in lower legs. She has been to a pain specialist and neurologist who have no answers. She is losing hope and trying to care for four children. Can you please offer us some answers?
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. I understand your concern and would explain that her symptoms (especially the grip loss in her arms and blurring vision) are not related to a lumbar spine disorder. A brain disorder (intracranial hypotension) or a cervical myelopathy could explain some of her symptoms. Intracranial hypotension could be a complication of local anesthesia, but you should know that it usually leads to a headache and blurring vision or nausea when standing up or sitting and the symptoms usually improve with lying down. So, it seems that her symptoms are not typical of this disorder too. Coming to this point, it is necessary to perform a brain MRI study and a cervical spine MRI study. The bilateral inflammation and swelling in her legs do not seem to be related to any neurological disorder. For this reason, it is important to perform inflammation tests (complete blood count, PCR, sedimentation rate) and a Doppler ultrasound of the leg vessels to investigate for chronic venous insufficiency. A cardiac ultrasound is necessary to exclude possible heart failure as a possible cause of increased fluid retention. Hope you will find this answer helpful. For more information consult a neurologist online
answer_chatgpt:
I am sorry to hear that your daughter has been experiencing such debilitating symptoms for such a long time. It sounds like she has been through a lot.

Based on the symptoms you have described, it is possible that your daughter may be suffering from a condition called arachnoiditis, which is inflammation of the arachnoid membrane that surrounds the spinal cord. This can be caused by spinal anesthesia or any other traumatic injury to the spine. The symptoms of arachnoiditis can be similar to those that your daughter is experiencing, including back pain, stiffness, loss of grip strength, shooting pains, and vision problems.

Unfortunately, arachnoiditis is a difficult condition to diagnose and treat. MRI scans may not always show evidence of inflammation, and treatment options are often limited to managing symptoms with pain medication and physical therapy.

However, it is important to rule out other conditions that may be contributing to your daughter's symptoms, such as a herniated disc or nerve damage. I would recommend that your daughter seek a second opinion from a neurosurgeon or spine specialist who is experienced in treating complex spine conditions. They may be able to offer additional diagnostic tests or treatment options that have not been considered yet.

Furthermore, her vascular issue with bilateral inflammation and swelling in the lower legs warrants thorough evaluation as well by a vascular specialist.

I hope this information is helpful, and I wish your daughter the best of luck in finding relief from her symptoms.

Would you recommend glucosamine, or something else?Also, do you think I can still reach my height goal? I am worried that I may have stunted my growth. That being said, nutrition can certainly impact your height potential. Calcium and protein are essential for bone growth and development, so it is important to make sure you are getting enough of these nutrients. While dairy products are a good source of calcium and protein, there are plenty of non-dairy sources as well, such as leafy greens, nuts, seeds, tofu, and fortified non-dairy milks. Aim for 3-4 servings of calcium-rich foods per day and 1-2 servings of protein-rich foods per meal.

In regards to glucosamine, while some studies have shown it to have potential benefits for joint health and inflammation, there is no solid evidence that it can increase height. It is always important to speak with a healthcare professional before starting any new supplement regimen.

As for your height goal, genetics plays a large role in determining height, so it is hard to say for sure if you will reach 5'9"-5'10". However, at 17 years old, you likely still have some growth potential left, so making sure you are getting adequate nutrition and taking care of your overall health is important for maximizing your height potential.

input: Hi doctor,I have acne scars. What are the treatments followed to make the acne scars go away?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Acne scar treatment depends on the type of scar. Boxcar scar is a superficial one. It can be treated with microdermabrasion combined with peel, and dermaroller. Ice pick scar is a small deep scar. It can be treated with TCA CROSS (Trichloro Acetic Acid chemical reconstruction of skin scars) procedure. Rolling scar needs subcision (minor surgical procedure) and fractional Co2 laser. Hypertrophic scar requires treatment using an intralesional injection of Triamcinolone acetonide to flatten it. Please attach your clinical picture soon so that I can guide you further.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! There are several treatments that can help reduce the appearance of acne scars. These include:

1. Chemical peels: A chemical solution is used to peel away the top layer of skin, which can reduce the visibility of acne scars.

2. Microdermabrasion: This treatment uses a machine to exfoliate the skin, removing dead skin cells and helping to reduce the appearance of scars.

3. Laser treatments: Various types of laser treatments are available that can help resurface the skin and reduce the appearance of scars.

4. Dermal fillers: Injectable fillers can be used to fill in depressed scars and improve their appearance.

5. Microneedling: This treatment involves using a device with small needles to create tiny punctures in the skin, which can stimulate collagen production and improve the appearance of scars.

It's important to talk to a dermatologist about which treatment is best for your specific type of acne scars. They can help you come up with a plan that's tailored to your skin and your goals.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi there, Acne scarring is a difficult problem to solve. Treating acne can help reduce the severity of scarring but it cannot reverse the damage that has already been done. The best way to improve existing acne scars is with laser resurfacing or chemical peels. These procedures work by removing the top layers of skin and stimulating collagen growth in the deeper layers. This helps to gradually replace damaged tissue with healthy new skin. However, these procedures do require some downtime so they may not be suitable for everyone. I would recommend consulting your dermatologist who will be able to assess your condition and advise you accordingly.

2. In the future, does this gap harm or shift adjacent teeth? I mean does this gap affect the functionality of front teeth as well as adjacent teeth?
Answer: Generally, a small gap between teeth does not cause harm or shift adjacent teeth, but it can contribute to food getting stuck between teeth and potential gum inflammation. It may also affect the way you bite or chew, but this is dependent on the severity of the gap.

3. What are its causes and is there any exercise to close this gap like pressing the teeth together for 10 to 15 seconds? If I do that exercise, does it affect the functionality of teeth in a negative way?

As for exercises to close the gap, some people claim that pressing the teeth together for a period of time can help, but this is not a proven method and may cause harm to the teeth if done too forcefully. It is always best to consult with a dental professional for personalized recommendations.

4. In short, do you need treatment for diastema if it is not showing any symptoms or not affecting day-to-day life?
Answer: If the gap is not causing any issues or discomfort, then it may not require treatment. However, if it is affecting your confidence or self-esteem, then treatment may be worth considering.

Based on the information you provided and the X-ray image, it appears that your gap is slight and does not require urgent treatment. However, if you would like to explore options to close the gap for cosmetic purposes, you can discuss them with your dental provider.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, Thanks for writing in. Diastema in your case is because of the space between the two upper central incisors. This space can be closed by orthodontics but it will take time. input: Hi doctor,My sister ate a bottle full of thyroid pills. She feels so weak and nervous every day. And she gets angry and her body temperature is always too warm and I searched the effect of too much of thyroid pills. Her age is 18 what should we do now?
answer_icliniq: Hi. Please visit the emergency department of any hospital and get a stomach wash done. The symptoms she is exhibiting is that of hyperthyroidism for which treatment is needed. It will increase heart rate, cause diarrhea, tremors of hand, anxiety, and agitation. Do not waste time. Take her to the nearest hospital urgently.
answer_chatgpt:
I'm sorry to hear about your sister's situation. Eating a bottle full of thyroid pills can result in serious health complications. It is important to seek medical help immediately. The thyroid hormone is responsible for regulating many functions in the body, including metabolism, heart rate, and body temperature. Excessive thyroid hormone can cause overactive thyroid, also known as hyperthyroidism, which can lead to symptoms such as anxiety, nervousness, irritability, palpitation, feeling hot, weight loss, diarrhea, and muscle weakness. In severe cases, hyperthyroidism can result in thyroid storm, which is a life-threatening medical emergency.

I would recommend taking your sister to the emergency department or contacting poison control immediately. In the meantime, keep monitoring her closely for any changes in symptoms and vital signs such as heart rate and blood pressure. Do not try to induce vomiting, as it can worsen the situation. The medical team will perform a thorough evaluation, including blood tests, electrocardiogram, and imaging tests to assess the extent of the overdose and provide appropriate treatment. Treatment may include medications, supportive care, or in some cases, hospitalization.
answer_chatdoctor: 1000 mg of thyroxine per day is an excessive amount to take for any adult let alone someone who is only 18 years old. It can cause symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, tremors, nervousness, irritability, increased heart rate, and weight loss. The thyroxine dose needs to be reduced. If your sister has been taking this dosage for some time, then she may also need to go through a period of tapered doses in order to allow the thyroid gland to reset itself. In addition, it is important to make sure that there aren't other underlying causes of hyperthyroidism such as Graves disease or a goiter.

input: Hello doctor,I want to perform PC muscle exercises. Will you guide me on how to locate it?
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. PC exercises (pubococcygeus muscle) are performed basically to improve the sexual performance in men, to delay the ejaculation. To locate PC muscle, it is located in the perineum area behind the scrotum and in front of the anus. It is deep to skin and soft tissue, and urethra passes through this muscle. Hence contraction of this muscle helps to delay ejaculation by compressing urethra. The exercises for the PC muscles includes sitting with a straight back, both hands on lap. Squeeze in the anus as if trying to hold bowel while defecating. Hold and count to 10 and then slowly release the muscle. Do this for 6 to 10 times per sitting. Every day you can have 4 to 5 such sittings. While passing urine, what you can do is hold urine for 1 to 2 seconds, then, pass it, then again hold. This hold-pass can be done 3 to 4 times every time you go for a pee. Both these measures help in strengthening the PC muscle. All you need is to have patience. It will need time to show results.

2. Try to identify your PC muscle by contracting your muscles in the area so as to feel a tightening or squeezing sensation. This is the PC muscle contracting.

3. If you still need help, you can try stopping the flow of urine while you are urinating. The muscle that you use to do this is your PC muscle.

Once you have located your PC muscle, you can start doing Kegel exercises to strengthen it. Kegel exercises involve repeatedly contracting and relaxing the PC muscle. These exercises help to improve bladder control and sexual function.

For example, ultrasound imaging may be used to diagnose and monitor hydronephrosis, and can be repeated as needed without significant radiation exposure. In some cases, a kidney function study (nuclear renogram) may be used to evaluate kidney function and the presence of obstruction, which involves minimal radiation exposure. 

Invasive treatments, such as a surgical procedure to remove the obstruction or stent placement, may also be an option in some cases. These procedures involve risks such as bleeding, infection, and possible complications with anesthesia, but usually don't involve significant radiation exposure. 

The decision to remove a kidney is a complex one and should be made after careful consideration of multiple factors, including the extent of the hydronephrosis and the overall health of the patient. Removal of a kidney may have potential long-term effects on kidney function and overall health, and is generally reserved as a last resort. 

It's also important to note that radiation exposure from medical procedures is generally low and the risk of developing radiation-related cancer is small. However, it's always a good idea to discuss your concerns with your healthcare provider and ask about any potential risks and benefits of any recommended treatments. 

I hope this information was helpful. Please let me know if you have any additional questions or concerns.

Hello! First of all, congratulations on making the decision to quit smoking. It is a difficult addiction to break, but the benefits to your health will be significant.

Nicotine replacement therapy, such as Nicotex, can be helpful in managing cravings and withdrawal symptoms. However, it is not a standalone solution for quitting smoking. It is important to combine it with other methods, such as behavioral therapy, counseling, or support groups.

Here are some steps you can take to stop smoking:

1. Set a quit date: Choose a specific date when you will stop smoking completely.

2. Get support: Inform your family and friends about your plans to quit smoking. You can also join a support group or seek professional help.

3. Identify your triggers: Figure out what triggers your craving for cigarettes, such as stress or social situations.

4. Plan alternatives: Plan alternative activities for when you feel the urge to smoke, such as taking a walk, chewing gum or having a healthy snack.

5. Exercise regularly: Exercise can help reduce anxiety and manage cravings.

6. Manage withdrawal symptoms: Expect to experience withdrawal symptoms such as irritability, anxiety, and difficulty concentrating. Practice deep breathing, relaxation techniques or use nicotine replacement therapy.

Remember, quitting smoking is a process and it might take time to see the benefits. Be patient with yourself and ask for help when needed. Good luck on your journey to a healthier lifestyle!

answer_chatgpt:
Dear,

Thank you for reaching out regarding your symptoms. Based on your description, it is likely that you are suffering from a condition known as patulous eustachian tube dysfunction. This occurs when the eustachian tube (a narrow tube that connects the middle ear to the back of your nose and throat) remains partially open or fails to close properly. This can cause a variety of symptoms, including distorted hearing, increased breath sounds, and loud swallowing or chewing.

In terms of treatment options, your doctor may have prescribed medication in the past, such as nasal decongestants or antihistamines, which can help reduce inflammation and improve eustachian tube function. In addition, there are some lifestyle changes you can make to help manage your symptoms, such as avoiding tobacco smoke and allergens, staying hydrated, and trying to maintain a healthy weight.

If your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be necessary to explore other treatment options, such as inserting a small tube into the eardrum to help equalize pressure, or undergoing surgery to close the eustachian tube.

In order to determine the best course of action for your individual case, I would recommend scheduling a follow-up appointment with your doctor, who can perform a physical exam and review your medical history to develop a personalized treatment plan.

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a combination of antiretroviral drugs given to people who may have been exposed to HIV through sexual contact, needle-sharing, or other means. PEP can reduce the likelihood of HIV infection, but it is most effective when started as soon as possible after exposure (ideally within 72 hours) and taken consistently.

If you are concerned about your risk of HIV infection, it is best to talk to a healthcare provider who can evaluate your individual situation and recommend appropriate testing and treatment options.

input: Hi doctor,I have dengue from the last three days. The platelets have dropped from 197 to 129 today. I have the following questions: My fever fluctuates between 101 to 104 despite having Paracetamol. Is that normal? Also, when should I get admitted to the hospital? When does the body start producing or rising its platelets? I feel the very reason we do fluids therapy is for the body to do it on its own. Correct me if I am wrong. Any help will be much appreciated.
answer_icliniq: Hello. Hope this helps. Please feel free to ask more if you need further assistance. For more information consult an internal medicine physician online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

I'm sorry to hear that you have dengue. Dengue fever is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes that results in a sudden onset of fever, body aches, headache, and a rash. In some cases, it can cause a decrease in the number of platelets in the blood, which can lead to bleeding problems.

Regarding your questions:
- Fever fluctuations are common in dengue, and it's normal to experience it despite taking antipyretics like Paracetamol. It's essential to keep taking Paracetamol at regular intervals, as fever can cause dehydration and other complications. 
- Regarding hospital admission, it depends on the severity of your symptoms and platelet count. Usually, hospitalization is recommended if the platelet count drops below 100,000/cmm, and there are signs of bleeding or hemoconcentration. However, if you experience severe symptoms, such as severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, or difficulty breathing, you should seek medical attention immediately. 
- The body usually starts producing new platelets after 2-3 days of illness. However, the recovery period may vary from person to person, and factors like age, overall health, and the severity of the infection can affect it.
- Fluids therapy is necessary to prevent dehydration and maintain the fluid balance in the body. It's a supportive measure that can help the body fight the infection and produce new blood cells, including platelets.

Please follow your doctor's recommendations, keep yourself well-hydrated, rest adequately, and continue taking medication. Regular follow-up with your doctor and monitoring of your platelet count is crucial, especially if it continues to decrease. I hope you recover soon.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Fluctuation of temperature in dengue is normal and happens due to rise and fall in antibody level which is also known as cytokine release.  It doesn't mean you need to take any medicine for that. 2) Platelet production depends upon many factors like type of virus, severity of disease etc. but generally takes about 5-7 days after the symptoms subside. 3) Yes, you can go home once your platelets become more than 100.

input: Hi doctor,Is it safe to do strength training for osteoporosis? Does strength training improve the bone mineral density? What type of exercise or movement are good for osteoporosis? Which one has to be avoided, and why? What are the signs and symptoms seen in osteoporosis? When it has to be diagnosed in everyone?
answer_icliniq: Hi, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Strength training is not safe, and it is highly recommended in osteoporosis. It helps to increase the bone mineral density. Do workouts that keep the spine straight such as squatting. Try to strengthen your back muscles. Have workouts on your hip and spine. Do cardio exercise along with these workouts. Have a regular walking. You have to avoid activity that involves the bending of the spine. Avoid doing the heavy lifting. Osteoporosis has to be screened in persons who reach menopause, persons having a history of fracture frequently after 40 years of age and persons with family history. Individuals having back pain, pain in the knee joint, and having fractures frequently has to be screened for osteoporosis. It has to be tested for men above 60 years of age and women above 45 years of age.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! Yes, strength training can be safe and effective for individuals with osteoporosis, as it can help improve bone mineral density and reduce the risk of fractures. However, it is important to work with a qualified healthcare professional or certified personal trainer who has experience working with individuals with osteoporosis to ensure that exercises are appropriate and performed safely.

Strength training exercises can include weight-bearing exercises such as walking, jumping, or using resistance bands, as these can promote bone growth and increase bone density. It is important to also include exercises that target the major muscle groups, such as the back, hips, and thighs, as these can help improve balance and reduce the risk of falls.

Exercises that involve bending, twisting, or high-impact movements may need to be avoided, as they can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis. It is also important for individuals with osteoporosis to avoid exercises that involve rounding or arching of the spine, as this can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

Signs and symptoms of osteoporosis can include back pain, loss of height over time, stooped posture, and fractures, particularly in the wrist, hip, or spine. Osteoporosis is typically diagnosed through a bone mineral density test, which may be recommended for individuals over the age of 50 or for those who are at increased risk for osteoporosis due to certain medical conditions or medications.
answer_chatdoctor: 1) Yes, strength training is very helpful in improving the bone mineral density. 2) The best exercises that can help with osteoporosis are weight-bearing exercises like walking, jogging, stair climbing, running, etc., as well as resistance/weight training (strength training).3) Avoid any sudden jerky movements and avoid lifting heavy weights.4) Symptoms include back pain, loss of height, stooped posture, fractures, loss of muscle mass, thinning of the skin, brittle nails, and decreased stamina.5) Diagnosis should be done by taking an X-ray of the hips and spine.6) Osteoporosis is a condition where there is decrease in the amount of calcium in your bones. This causes them to become weak and more prone to fractures.

Congratulations on your pregnancy and I'm sorry to hear about your health complications. Here are some recommendations that may help you during your pregnancy:

1. Diet: Eat a well-balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Avoid undercooked or raw meat and fish, as well as unpasteurized dairy products. Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated.

2. Exercise: Light physical activity is usually recommended during pregnancy, but you should discuss with your doctor before starting or continuing any exercise regimen. Gentle exercises like walking, swimming or prenatal yoga may be beneficial.

3. Sleep: Get plenty of sleep during pregnancy and try to establish a regular sleep pattern. Proper rest can help reduce stress levels.

4. Stress management: Stress can be harmful to your health and your growing baby. Identify your stressors and find ways to manage them. Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing, visualization, or meditation.

5. Work: It is advisable to avoid any strenuous or stressful work, especially during the first trimester. However, if you must work, try to take frequent breaks, avoid heavy lifting or standing for prolonged periods of time. You may also discuss reasonable accommodations with your employer.

In your case, given your health complications, it is advisable to take bed rest as recommended by your doctor. Returning to work may not be suitable at this time. The stress associated with work may be detrimental to your health and the health of your growing baby. However, it is best to consult with your doctor and discuss your concerns regarding your financial issues. Your doctor may be able to provide you with further guidance and support.

Regarding the uterus stitching, it is a medical procedure that needs to be done under the supervision of a qualified healthcare professional. You may discuss the procedure in detail with your doctor and seek their advice on the best course of action for your individual case.

Take good care of yourself and your growing baby. Follow your doctor's advice, eat well, rest well, and manage stress levels to ensure a healthy pregnancy.

However, given that you had protected sex and took emergency contraception, the chances of pregnancy are quite low. Nevertheless, it is still possible to get pregnant even with the use of protection and emergency contraception.

The symptoms you're experiencing could be related to hormonal changes caused by emergency contraception, or it could be a sign of an oncoming period.

To rule out pregnancy, you could take a home pregnancy test, which is typically accurate 2-3 weeks after the unprotected intercourse. If the test is negative, it is likely that your period is just delayed due to the emergency contraceptive you took.

However, if the test is positive, make an appointment with your healthcare provider to discuss your options and next steps.

If the test is negative and your period still hasn't come after a week or so, consider making an appointment with your healthcare provider to rule out any other underlying causes for the delay or consult with them about ways to regulate your menstrual cycle.

In general, it is important to take care of your overall health and well-being, including practicing safe sex, maintaining a healthy diet, and managing stress. If you have any other concerns or questions, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider for guidance.

Then, I would ask both female and male patients to run a thyroid function test. While female patients to also check sexual hormone levels in the blood. Stress makes it difficult to fall asleep and keep asleep and altering sleep quality. Hormonal changes will cause an increase in body heat (which becomes not stable) and a ChatDoctor.  Estrogen will cause an increase in body fat in women more around the tummy. This will cause snoring and sleep apnea. We should ask patients more details about their sleep like, is it difficult to fall asleep? Why? Do you wake up during the night? How many times if yes? Why? In this way, we will find more details about the sleeping problems my patients are having. Sometimes, they can sleep but they are so anxious and feel not enough to sleep.
answer_chatgpt:
There are many possible causes of sleep disturbances, including:

1. Stress and anxiety
2. Hormonal imbalances such as menstrual cycle, pregnancy or menopause
3. Medications 
4. Medical conditions such as sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome or chronic pain
5. Environmental factors such as noise, light or temperature 
6. Poor sleep habits and lifestyle factors such as caffeine, alcohol, and irregular sleep schedule.

If you are experiencing sleep disturbances, it can be helpful to keep a sleep diary to track your sleeping patterns and any potential triggers such as stress, caffeine intake or hormonal fluctuations. If you suspect that stress and anxiety are the primary cause of your sleep troubles, you may experience symptoms such as racing thoughts, worry and difficulty relaxing. On the other hand, if your sleep disturbances are caused by hormonal imbalances you may experience changes in your menstrual pattern or other physical symptoms such as hot flashes.

To address hormonal causes of sleep disturbances, it is important to address hormonal changes through medication or natural remedies. For stress and anxiety-related sleep disturbances, stress-reduction techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, and exercise can be helpful. In addition, establishing good sleep hygiene practices such as creating a relaxing bedtime routine, maintaining a regular sleep schedule and avoiding caffeine and other stimulants can improve sleep quality regardless of the underlying cause. It is important to speak to your healthcare provider about any chronic or severe sleep disturbances to identify the root cause and explore appropriate treatment options.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, thanks for posting your query at Chat Doctor. There are many reasons for poor sleep. Poor sleep or insomnia can also be due to some underlying medical conditions like thyroid dysfunction or other endocrinological disorders. To know whether it is due to stress/anxiety or something else, I would suggest you to consult a psychiatrist who will help in identifying the cause and treat accordingly.

Week six (42 days) did another fourth generation and was negative. 52 days little over seven weeks I went and did an HIV 2 RNA test, and today at 53 days did an HIV RNA test and fourth generation duo. After all, these tests, am I in the clear? If I had HIV symptoms for a few weeks already would I test positive by now? Does it matter if I got her tested to give me reassurance?

Additionally, HIV symptoms can vary widely and are not always a reliable indicator of infection. Some people may experience flu-like symptoms within a few weeks of exposure, while others may not show any symptoms for years.

Although getting your partner tested for HIV can provide some reassurance, it is ultimately up to you to take responsibility for your own sexual health. It is important to continue practicing safe sex and getting regular HIV testing if you are sexually active with multiple partners.

If you continue to experience symptoms or have concerns about your HIV status, it is important to speak with a healthcare provider who can provide you with personalized advice and testing options.

If the surrogate is Kell-positive, there is a risk that the fetus could also be Kell-positive, which could trigger Kell alloimmunization in your husband. This can cause hemolytic disease in the fetus or newborn, which could result in severe anemia, jaundice, brain damage, and even death.

Your doctor will likely recommend that the surrogate undergo a blood test to determine her Kell status. If she is Kell-negative, the risk of Kell alloimmunization is significantly reduced. However, if she is Kell-positive, your doctor may recommend that your husband undergo genetic counseling and possibly receive prophylactic treatment to reduce the risk of Kell alloimmunization.

It is important to discuss these risks with your doctor and seek their advice on the best course of action for your specific situation.

input: Hello doctor,My father had an echo test. The report says \Mildly dilated LA. Normal LV size, with moderately reduced function. Mild MR. LVDD II\. What does it mean?
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. Did he have any chest pain or heart attack in the past, or is he diabetic? To summarize the report, it says there is a decreased functioning of the heart, which most commonly occurs due to coronary artery disease or sometimes due to the weakening of the heart muscle. So, he should get his evaluation done, ECG (electrocardiogram), lipid profile, sugars both fasting and post lunch, and angiography. He should be on medicine to prevent further decline in the heart functions which includes Aspirin, Clopidogrel, statins like Atorvastatin, beta blockers like Metoprolol, ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitor like Ramipril, and diuretics like Spironolactone, etc. Hope this helps you and get back if you have any doubts. For more information consult a cardiologist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! 

Based on the report you have provided, here is what it means:

1. Mildly dilated LA: This means that the left atrium (LA) of the heart is slightly enlarged. An enlarged LA may be a sign of underlying heart problems.

2. Normal LV size: The left ventricle (LV) of the heart is the main pumping chamber. Normal LV size indicates that it is not enlarged.

3. Moderately reduced function: This means that the left ventricle is not functioning as well as it should be. The reduced function indicates that the heart is not pumping blood efficiently, which can lead to problems.

4. Mild MR: MR stands for mitral regurgitation, which is a condition in which blood flows backward into the heart. Mild MR means that the amount of blood flowing backward is not severe.

5. LVDD II: LVDD stands for left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, which means that the left ventricle is not filling with blood properly during its resting phase. LVDD II is a mild form of diastolic dysfunction.

Overall, the report suggests that your father has mild heart problems, including an enlarged LA, moderately reduced LV function, mild MR, and mild diastolic dysfunction. He should follow up with a cardiologist to determine the underlying cause of these issues and plan on any necessary treatment.
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, I understand your concern and would explain that such an echo is not abnormal. It means that there is a mild dilation of the left atrium (LA) which is a normal variant in some people. This dilation can be considered as a sign of a possible mitral valve disease. However, this is just a hypothesis and needs to be confirmed by other investigations like an ECG or a cardiac ultrasound. In addition, a complete blood count should be done for a possible anemia. Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.

Externally induced hormone interferes with the periods to prevent conception by stopping fertilization, ovulation or implantation. The symptoms your partner is experiencing could be related to pregnancy, but they could also be caused by other factors such as hormonal changes or a menstrual cycle. It's also important to note that breast changes or nipple pain aren't always present during early pregnancy.

As for the effectiveness of the emergency contraceptive pill (ECP), like I-Pill, they are most effective when taken within the first 24-48 hours after unprotected sex. After ten days, the effectiveness of the ECP decreases significantly, and taking another pill now won't be effective against preventing pregnancy.

It's recommended that your partner takes a pregnancy test after three weeks from the date of unprotected sex to confirm whether she is pregnant or not. If the pregnancy test is positive, she should seek medical advice.

Going forward, it's important to use condoms correctly and consistently during sexual intercourse to prevent unwanted pregnancies and the spread of sexually transmitted infections.

In most cases, this works. The next step beyond this is Gaviscon (antacid) and feed thickening. 3. Also very important is to keep the child in a slightly upright position (30 degrees to ground) after feeding (and most of the time) to reduce the amount of discomfort the child may be facing due to reflux. In terms of the lack of bowel movements, it is not uncommon for breastfed babies to go several days without a bowel movement. However, if your baby seems uncomfortable and is straining to poop, you can try some gentle tummy massage and leg bicycling to help him pass stool. If you're concerned, don't hesitate to contact your pediatrician for further advice.

As for the Colicaid and Yamoo, these are both commonly used to help with colic and gas. However, every baby is unique and may respond differently. If you are not seeing improvement, you can discuss other options with your pediatrician.

Overall, it's important to remember that digestive issues in babies are common and often resolve on their own as their digestive system develops. It may take some trial and error to find what works best for your baby, so don't hesitate to reach out to your pediatrician for guidance.

answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

Based on your MRI report, you have mild posterior protrusions from the C3-4 to C5-6 levels that are causing an indentation of the thecal sac. This may be contributing to your neck pain and stiffness.

As a desk worker who sits for 8 to 10 hours a day on the computer, it's essential to take frequent breaks and change positions to reduce the risk of aggravating your condition. You can also do some simple exercises or stretches to improve your neck's mobility, relieve stress and assist in managing the pain.

Some of the exercises which may help you in reducing the pain are:

1. Neck rotations: Keep your head straight and then gently rotate your neck as if you are looking to your left and then to the right. Repeat 5-10 times.

2. Neck tilts: Tilt your head to the left, hold for a few seconds, relax, and then repeat on the right side.

3. Shoulder shrugs: Slowly lift your shoulders, squeeze and hold for a few seconds, and then lower them.

4. Wall Angles: With your back against a wall, bend your elbows, and raise your arms to form a W shape. Slowly move your arms up and down, maintaining your elbows and fingers in contact with the wall.

While performing the above exercises or stretches, focus on breathing. Slow inhale through the nose, and exhale with the mouth.

Although exercise can provide relief, it's important to incorporate it with other management strategies such as improving posture, taking breaks, and reducing workplace stress to help the condition heal. It's advisable to consult with an Orthopedic Specialist or Physical Therapist for further assessment and guidelines.

Hope this information helps you. If you have any further questions, please feel free to ask.

input: Hello doctor,A back molar was sore when I chewed on it and my dentist found an infection under it, so he did a root canal but afterward, it was still sore. Your dentist took appropriate steps in diagnosing and addressing the issue with the infected tooth. The decision to perform the root canal procedure first before determining the need for removal would depend on the initial diagnosis and treatment plan. In your case, it sounds like the root canal procedure was a reasonable approach initially.

input: Hi doctor, I have Pericoronitis (swelling and pain behind the wisdom tooth). I went to the dentist yesterday and he cleaned my mouth and gave me antibiotics (Penicillin V) and Ibuprofen 600. I have been taking the antibiotics for two days now and I do not feel an improvement. Is this normal? How long does it normally take until it starts getting better? Should I go back to my dentist tomorrow? I take Ibuprofen but it only lasts for two to three hours. I am also using Chlorhexamed forte.
answer_icliniq: Hello,  Welcome to ChatDoctor.  I understand your concern. The loosely attached swollen gums over the wisdom tooth is called as pericoronitis. The age of eruption of wisdom teeth is from 17 to 21 years. Beyond that, if the wisdom tooth has not erupted or half erupted gives out pain or swelling, it is highly likely to be locked inside the jaw.  Since they are the last ones to erupt, most of them do not get enough space to erupt and tries anyways and this causes jaw pain, swelling and sometimes the surrounding structures like same side temple, ear and throat also gives out pain. This wisdom tooth is called an impacted tooth. During the first visit, antibiotics and painkillers will be prescribed. The swelling will come down eventually but if that is impacted, it may not come down. Please visit your dentist and get an x-ray of your wisdom tooth to check whether there is enough space for it to erupt and to check whether it is erupting in the right direction. Taking painkillers and antibiotics will help to control pain and swelling but if the tooth is impacted, this will not be a permanent solution. You may require wisdom tooth removal.  I hope this helps.

Your dentist may need to re-evaluate the situation and potentially prescribe a different antibiotic or a higher dose. In the meantime, you can continue taking the Ibuprofen as directed by your dentist and using the Chlorhexamed forte for pain relief and to promote healing. Make sure to practice good oral hygiene habits and avoid eating or drinking foods that may irritate the affected area.

Small pulmonary nodules are common and can be caused by a variety of factors, including infections or inflammation. However, they can also be a sign of lung cancer, especially if they are growing or changing over time. 

In your case, as the nodules are small and not suspicious for cancer, your doctor may have recommended a watchful waiting approach. This means that they will monitor the nodules over time to see if they grow or change on follow-up scans. If they do not change, there may be no need for further intervention.

It's important to follow up with your doctor as advised and continue to monitor your symptoms. If you have ongoing chest pain, it may be worth discussing further testing or treatment options with your doctor to rule out any underlying conditions.

Based on the details you've provided, the risk of contracting HIV from performing oral sex on a female is considered low, but not zero. This is because saliva contains enzymes that can break down and inactivate the virus, but there is still a theoretical risk if there was blood or other bodily fluids present. Fingering and masturbating do not typically transmit HIV, unless there was blood or other bodily fluids present and there were open wounds or breaks in the skin.

Your negative HIV test at 25 days is encouraging, but it's important to note that the window period for HIV can vary and some people may take longer to develop detectable antibodies. The health department may have recommended against retesting because the Alere combo test is considered highly sensitive and specific, but a repeat test at a later time period (such as 3 months post-exposure) could provide additional reassurance.

It's possible that your physical symptoms could be related to anxiety and stress, which can manifest in physical ways. However, it's also important to rule out any medical causes for your symptoms, especially if they persist or worsen. I would recommend discussing your symptoms with a healthcare provider and possibly getting a physical exam and other tests as needed.

Lastly, it's important to seek support for your emotional well-being as well. Infidelity and potential exposure to HIV can be very distressing and it's important to have resources to help cope with these feelings. This could include therapy, support groups, or talking with trusted friends or family members.

I hope this information is helpful and reassuring. Please feel free to ask any follow-up questions or concerns.

input: Hello doctor,Is having a filling material applied to the gumline where it is receding a good solution? What are the risks with such a procedure? I have receding gums on three upper teeth and three lower teeth on the left. I have no pain or problems. I have all my teeth and they are generally healthy.
answer_icliniq: Hi. I have read through your medical history and the present complaint as well. First of all, I would like you to know that receding gums is such a normal thing to happen especially at your age. You have also mentioned that there is no pain or decay in those teeth you point out. Ideally, filling procedures do not work for gum recession problems but only for decay or abrasions close to the gum lines. The reason why fillings are not recommended is that you lose normal shiny tooth surface and the bulk while the cavities are prepared and there are many chances that the filling material might show microleakage hence paving way for tooth decay. There are as such no particular risks for this kind of procedures with your medical history kept in mind. But I also would like to take a look at those teeth which are of concern in order to help you with a better treatment plan. For more information consult a dentist online
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

A filling material applied to the gum line where it is receding is a common procedure known as gum grafting or gingival grafting. This type of procedure is used to treat gum tissue that has receded and exposed the root of the tooth. The filling material used can be a small piece of tissue from your own mouth, a synthetic material or a combination of both. The goal of gum grafting is to restore the gum line to cover the exposed tooth root, which can enhance the appearance of your smile and reduce your risk of tooth sensitivity or decay.

However, there are some risks associated with this procedure. The most common side effects are swelling, redness, and discomfort in the area where the graft was placed. There is also the possibility of infection, bleeding, and graft failure. Additionally, there may be some restrictions on eating and chewing for a few days after the procedure.

It is important to consult with your dentist or periodontist to determine the best course of treatment for your specific case. They may recommend other treatments such as scaling and root planing or antibiotics before proceeding with gum grafting.

input: Hi doctor,I am concerned about the medication that my 13 year old son is currently taking for bipolar disorder. He was diagnosed bipolar disorder at the age of 7. His past medicines are Intuniv and Depakote and his current medicines are Zoloft and Vyvanse. I have tried speaking with my son\s therapist. However, my ex-husband has told her not to speak to me regarding my son\s treatment. I have noticed in conversations as well as visits with my son that he sometimes seems more depressed and agitated even threatening to run away from home. Is Zoloft used to treat bipolar without any secondary medication? Is it safe for a 13 year old?
answer_icliniq: Hi. First of all, I want to inform you that Vyvanse (Lisdexamfetamine) and Intuniv (Guanfacine) tablets are indicated for Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Depakote (Valproic acid) is an antiepileptic and mood stabilizer. It is useful for bipolar disorder. If your child is diagnosed with bipolar, then he should receive Depakote or other mood stabilizer. Zoloft (Sertraline) is an antidepressant and by this chance of switch to mania is there. So, in bipolar patients if depressive symptoms are prominent, then antidepressant can be given only under the cover of mood stabilizer. Antidepressant should not be used for long term in bipolar patients. Once depressive symptoms get resolve, patient should maintain only on mood stabilizer. Antidepressant should get taper off gradually.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello, I understand your concerns regarding your son's medication for bipolar disorder. Zoloft (sertraline) is an antidepressant medication that is frequently used in combination with other medications for bipolar disorder, but it is not typically used as the sole medication for bipolar disorder. It is important to note, however, that each individual's symptoms and the nature of their bipolar disorder can vary, and the medication regimen will depend on the specific needs and response of the patient under the care of a certified professional.

While Zoloft is considered generally safe, there are risks associated with the use of antidepressants in children and adolescents, including an increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior. Therefore, it is critical that your son's healthcare practitioner closely monitor any potential side effects, changes in symptoms, and overall response to the medication.

It is also concerning that your ex-husband has prohibited your son's therapist from speaking with you regarding your son's treatment. It is important for all parties involved in the care of your son to communicate and work collaboratively to ensure that he receives the best possible care.

In summary, while Zoloft can be an effective medication for treating depression, it is typically used in conjunction with other medications for bipolar disorder. It is crucial that your son's healthcare provider closely monitors his symptoms and response to the medication, and that there is ongoing communication between all parties involved in his care.

input: Hello doctor,Why some men cannot grow full beards? Explain why some men are not capable of growing full beards, and can only manage thin, patchy ones. answer_chatgpt:
Hello! The ability to grow a full beard is largely dependent on genetics and testosterone levels. Testosterone is the hormone that stimulates and controls the growth of facial hair, and genetics determine how sensitive the hair follicles are to testosterone.

Some men may have lower levels of testosterone or less sensitivity to the hormone, which can result in thin or patchy beard growth. Other factors such as age, health, and diet may also play a role in beard growth.

Not being able to grow a full beard can potentially impact men psychologically, causing feelings of inadequacy or emasculation. This can affect self-esteem and even lead to social anxiety. However, it is important to note that not being able to grow a full beard does not define one's masculinity or worth as a person.

If a man is struggling with patchy beard growth, there are a few things he can do to improve it. Eating a balanced diet and getting enough sleep and exercise can help boost testosterone levels naturally. Using a beard oil or serum can also help to nourish and stimulate the hair follicles. If these methods do not work, there are also medical treatments such as minoxidil or hair transplant surgery available. However, it is important to speak with a doctor or dermatologist before trying any treatments.

5. Maintain a healthy diet: A healthy diet that includes plenty of vitamins and minerals can help promote healthy hair growth. Be sure to include foods like salmon, nuts, and leafy greens in your diet.

Its important to remember that results may vary and it may take some time for any of these methods to work. Be patient and consistent with your efforts, and you should begin to see some improvement in the thickness and length of your eyebrows and eyelashes.

Here are a few things you can do to improve your skin:

1. Cleanse your skin: Wash your face regularly with a gentle, soap-free face wash. Avoid using harsh scrubs or chemicals that may irritate your skin.

2. Moisturize: Use a lightweight, oil-free moisturizer to keep your skin hydrated.

3. Avoid touching your face: Avoid touching your face too often or resting your chin on your hands. This can transfer bacteria from your hands to your face and may worsen acne.

4. Eat a healthy diet: Eating a balanced diet that is rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins can help your skin look and feel better.

6. Avoid stress: High levels of stress can contribute to acne. Practice stress-reducing techniques like meditation or yoga.

7. Consult a dermatologist: If your acne does not improve with these measures, consulting a dermatologist may help. They may recommend topical or oral medications to help clear your acne.

Hope this helps!

Cortisone injections and special boots are standard treatments for plantar fasciitis, but they do not always provide relief for everyone. In some cases, surgery may be necessary.

An MRI can be helpful in diagnosing and evaluating the severity of plantar fasciitis. It can show if there is any degeneration or tearing of the plantar fascia or if there is a problem with the surrounding soft tissues.

Levoxyl is a medication used to treat low thyroid hormone levels, and Paxil is an antidepressant medication. These medications are not directly related to plantar fasciitis but may have an impact on pain perception and management.

I suggest discussing your MRI results with your doctor to determine the best course of treatment for your condition.

1. What do you think is the most common and most damaging misconception people have when it comes to purchasing food in the supermarket?

One of the most common misconceptions is that food products that are advertised as "low-fat," "reduced-fat," or "light" are healthier options. In reality, many of these products may have added sugars, making them just as unhealthy as their full-fat counterparts.

2. Do you think that people focus too much on calorie counting and not enough on eating healthy foods? If you can include only three things in a nutritional label, what would you choose?

Calorie counting is an essential part of maintaining a healthy weight, but it is not the only aspect of healthy eating. It is important to focus on the quality of the calories you consume, and not just the quantity. If I could only include three things in a nutritional label, I would choose total sugars, ingredients, and serving size.

3. In your experience, what do people mostly focus on when studying nutritional labels, calories, fats, or sodium? What do you think they should be focusing on the most?

People tend to focus on calories and fat content when studying nutritional labels, but they should also pay attention to the sugar and sodium content. Foods with high levels of added sugar and sodium can lead to health problems like high blood pressure and diabetes.

4. In your opinion, how can people make more educated decisions when grocery shopping? Do you think the nutritional label is enough to rely on?

Reading the nutritional labels is a great start, but people should also pay attention to the ingredients list and try to choose whole, unprocessed foods as much as possible. It is also important to educate oneself on what constitutes a healthy, balanced diet.

5. If you were to design a completely new nutritional label, how would you make it easier to understand or read than the previous five examples of nutritional labels? Do you have any suggestions?

Some suggestions for a more user-friendly nutritional label include displaying the total and added sugar content separately, and providing clear and concise information on the serving size and number of servings per package.

6. Of the many food trends that constantly spring up, should the average consumer believe any slogan slapped across the packaging of food products? What are some tell-tale signs to be aware of?

Consumers should be wary of slogans like "all natural" or "organic," as they do not always guarantee that the product is healthy. It is important to read the ingredients list and nutritional labels to get a complete picture of what is in the food product.

In terms of medication, there are several options for reducing inflammation and managing pain. These include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), and biologic drugs. Prednisone is a type of steroid that can reduce inflammation, but it is not typically used as a long-term treatment due to its potential side effects.

DMARDs such as methotrexate and sulfasalazine can slow the progression of the disease and prevent joint damage. Biologic drugs such as Enbrel, Humira, and Remicade can also reduce inflammation and prevent joint damage.

In addition to medication, physical therapy and exercise can also help manage pain and improve joint flexibility. Your mother may also benefit from alternative therapies such as acupuncture, massage therapy, or cognitive behavioral therapy.

Overall, it is important for your mother to follow up with a rheumatologist to receive proper diagnosis and treatment.

I have consulted a lot of dermatologists but there is no improvement. I do not want any wonder results but I need some improvement. I was very depressed by this condition. Please suggest any lotion or cream to solve my problem.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. This is genetic and you cannot do anything about it with lotions and medicines. There is a temporary procedure called dermal fillers which will give fullness and youth to your hands and legs but that is not cheap and the results last for nine months to one year. If you are interested in these procedures you can meet a cosmetic dermatologist or plastic surgeon who does fillers.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello,

I am sorry to hear about your skin concerns. Loose skin and wrinkles can be caused by various factors such as genetics, aging, dehydration, and sun damage.

While there are many creams and lotions available in the market that claim to tighten and firm skin, it is important to understand that topical products can only do so much. In order to see significant improvement in skin texture, it is important to address the underlying causes.

Here are some tips that may help improve the appearance of your skin:

1. Stay hydrated- Drink plenty of water throughout the day to keep your skin hydrated and plump.

2. Sun protection- Wearing SPF is crucial to prevent further damage to the skin. Make sure to apply sunscreen with at least SPF 30 every day, even if you are staying indoors.

3. Exercise regularly- Regular exercise helps in improving blood circulation and promoting collagen production, which can help improve skin elasticity.

4. Eat a healthy diet- Consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and protein can also help improve skin health.

5. Consider professional treatments- In-office treatments such as chemical peels, microdermabrasion, and laser therapy can help improve skin texture and firmness.

It is important to consult with a dermatologist or a skincare professional before trying any new treatments or products, as they can recommend the best course of action based on your individual needs.

Regards,
Dr. [Your Name]
answer_chatdoctor: Hi, thanks for writing in. The ageing process involves many factors like genetic, environmental, lifestyle etc. In your case, the main factor seems to be the genetic predisposition which is quite common in people with fair complexion. You should apply a light moisturizer every day at night before sleep and a broad spectrum sunscreen (SPF 50) during the day. Apply a retinoid cream at night after cleansing your face. You can ask your dermatologist about the same. Hope this helps.

Here are some suggestions to help her overcome her symptoms:

1. Drink plenty of fluids: Encourage her to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids such as water, fruit juices, and soups.

2. Rest: Suggest her to take rest as much as possible. This can help to minimize dizziness and fatigue.

Lastly, it's important to encourage your friend to use reliable contraception to avoid the need for an ECP in the future.

I hope this helps!

There are several potential causes of sciatica, including a herniated disc, spinal stenosis, or piriformis syndrome. However, it's worth noting that some cases of sciatica have no identifiable cause.

In terms of treatment, the medications you are currently taking can be effective at managing the pain associated with sciatica. However, other treatment options may also be helpful, including physical therapy, exercise, and certain types of injections.

It's also worth noting that lifestyle changes may help, such as regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, and practicing good posture.

I recommend discussing your symptoms with your doctor or a specialist such as an orthopedist, neurologist or pain management specialist to determine the best course of action for you.

Anal skin tags are a common and usually benign condition that develops after healing of an anal fissure or other trauma. They may cause discomfort or irritation, but most of them are asymptomatic. In cases where the skin tags are symptomatic, surgical intervention is usually recommended.

Before undergoing surgery, you need to make sure that you are a suitable candidate for the procedure. Your doctor may do a thorough examination to rule out any underlying medical condition that may complicate the surgery. Depending on the size and location of the skin tags, a local or general anaesthetic may be used during the procedure.

Although surgery is generally considered safe, there can be some side effects or potential complications, such as infection, bleeding, pain, or damage to the anal muscles. You should discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor before making a decision.

It is also possible for skin tags to recur after surgery. However, this is more common if the underlying cause is not treated or if the surgical technique is not appropriate. Your doctor can discuss strategies to minimize the risk of recurrence with you.

In conclusion, if your skin tags are causing significant discomfort, you may consider surgical removal. However, it is important to discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor to make an informed decision.

input: Hello doctor,I wanted to know if you could answer one question for me. I checked my heart rate roughly three minutes after the incident and it was at 60 bpm and my oxygen was at 99 % under two weeks ago. I had a routine 24 tape which was clear (ectopic beats picked up but were benign). I suffer from anxiety and panic attacks. However, they generally come on during stressful situations. answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. This can be a cardiac arrhythmia like PSVT (paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia) or atrial fibrillation, in which heart rate suddenly goes up and also suddenly decreases. And one may get symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain or heaviness, dizziness, etc. Are you having ventricular or atrial ectopics? Have you undergone echo? Presence of ectopics also suggests the possibility of these arrhythmias. Usually, ECG is normal (attachment removed to protect patient identity) as it is done in between the episodes or may show ectopics. ECG done during episodes will show abnormality. You may request for portable cardiac monitor either Holter or another mobile-based rhythm monitor especially during intercourse to see the rhythm is recurring. Alternatively, you may undergo treadmill test and we can see if it recurs during the running.  Also, thyroid test should be done if not had recently. ln order to abort such episodes you should try to cough hard. Next time, you have this, focus on heart rate and measure pulse rate. These arrhythmias are not life-threatening. So overall, that episode may be an episode atrial arrhythmia rather than panic attack and our priority is to confirm it by investigations. Hope this helps you and get back if you have any doubts. For more information consult a cardiologist online

input: Hello doctor, Is a condom 100% safe? Can we get STDs through the body to body or skin to skin contact? By kissing will any std transmit? Is spa erotic massage safe? Please answer these questions it would be helpful.
answer_icliniq: Hello, Welcome to Chat Doctor forum. The condom does not give 100 percent contraception. In fact, no contraception is 100 percent effective. Body to body and skin to skin contact will not result in STD (sexually transmitted disease), unless there are cuts over the body and body fluids get transmitted. Kissing will not cause STD. Deep throat and violent kissing might cause injuries and microbleeds and those might cause transmission of fluids across membranes and STD. Spa erotic massage is usually safe.
answer_chatgpt:
Hello! Thank you for your questions. 

To answer your first question, a condom is highly effective at preventing the transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), but it is not 100% safe. The effectiveness of a condom depends on several factors such as the type of STI, the type of condom, and how it is used. While condoms can greatly reduce the risk of STI transmission, they are not foolproof.

Regarding your second question, it is possible to get some STIs through body-to-body or skin-to-skin contact, such as herpes or human papillomavirus (HPV). Therefore, it is important to use protective measures such as condoms and dental dams during sexual activities, even if penetration is not involved.

Regarding your third question, STD transmission through kissing is generally considered rare. However, certain STIs such as herpes and syphilis can be transmitted through kissing if there are active sores or lesions in or around the mouth. Additionally, kissing can be a way of transmitting STIs if the person you are engaging in sexual activity with has an STI in their throat or mouth.

As for your final question, it is difficult to assess the safety of spa erotic massage as it depends on the establishment and its practices. The risk of STI transmission can be increased in settings that do not practice safe sex measures, including the use of condoms and proper sanitation. It is important to remember that even in an intimate setting, such as a massage, it is still important to practice safe sex measures to protect against STI transmission.

Yes, skin to skin contact and mucous membrane to mucous membrane contact can transmit STDs.3. Kissing is generally safe unless there is blood in the mouth from gums, teeth, tongue or throat.4. answer_icliniq: Hi. Sorry to hear about your injury. Since your CT (computed tomography) scan is normal, it is very unlikely that there is any bony or skeletal injury hence reducing the possibility of something permanent. It appears that there is some soft tissue injury in the laryngopharyngeal region or a cartilaginous injury that is resolving very slowly. This indicates an injury closer to the voice box region because of constant movements during speech, laughter and swallowing delay recovery. This may also explain why it is taking so long to heal completely. In my opinion, an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) is certainly indicated since there has been no improvement in symptoms for five weeks and to look for cartilaginous injury or soft tissue lesions such as a granuloma or hematoma following trauma. In addition, a video laryngoscopy performed by an ENT will help to evaluate the voice box and supporting apparatus internally for any injury (specifically the inter arytenoid region). A hernia in the neck or a laryngocele may be a possibility following neck injury but seems very unlikely in your case since there is no visible bulge in the neck which worsens on coughing, etc. There may be an internal laryngocele that may be picked up on video laryngoscopy. I hope this helps.
